title: Minimum Additions to Make Valid String
question_content:
Given a string word to which you can insert letters "a", "b" or "c" anywhere and any number of times, return the minimum number of letters that must be inserted so that word becomes valid.
A string is called valid if it can be formed by concatenating the string "abc" several times.
 
Example 1:

Input: word = "b"
Output: 2
Explanation: Insert the letter "a" right before "b", and the letter "c" right next to "a" to obtain the valid string "abc".

Example 2:

Input: word = "aaa"
Output: 6
Explanation: Insert letters "b" and "c" next to each "a" to obtain the valid string "abcabcabc".

Example 3:

Input: word = "abc"
Output: 0
Explanation: word is already valid. No modifications are needed. 

 
Constraints:

	1 <= word.length <= 50
	word consists of letters "a", "b" and "c" only.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n)$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(1)$$
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution {
public:
    int addMinimum(string word) {
        int count = 0;
         for(int i = 0; i < word.size(); i++) {
             if(i == 0) {
                 if(word[i] == 'b') count++;
                 else if(word[i] == 'c') count += 2;
             }
             if(i == word.size() - 1) {
                 if(word[i] == 'a') count += 2;
                 else if(word[i] == 'b') count++;
             }
             else {
                 if(word[i] == word[i + 1]) count += 2;
                 else if(word[i] == 'a' && word[i + 1] == 'c') count++;
                 else if(word[i] == 'a' && word[i + 1] == 'c') count++;
                 else if(word[i] == 'b' && word[i + 1] == 'a') count++;
                 else if(word[i] == 'c' && word[i + 1] == 'b') count++;
             }
         }
        return count;
    }
};
```

solutions.title: explained-simple-and-clear-python3-code
solutions.content:
# Intuition
The problem requires us to determine the minimum number of letters that need to be inserted into a given string to make it valid. A valid string is defined as a string that can be formed by concatenating the string "abc" multiple times. To solve this problem, we can iteratively search for occurrences of "abc" and replace them with a placeholder, "---". Additionally, we also need to handle occurrences of "ab", "ac", and "bc" separately, replacing them with "--" while keeping track of the count. Finally, we count the remaining characters in the string that are not placeholders and add twice their count to the overall result.


# Approach
We initialize a variable count to keep track of the minimum number of letters that need to be inserted. We then proceed with the following steps:

1. While there is an occurrence of "abc" in the given word, we find its index i using the find function and replace it with "---" by modifying the word string.
2. Similarly, we search for occurrences of "ab", "ac", and "bc" in the word string using the find function. For each occurrence found, we replace it with "--" and increment the count by 1.
3. After handling all occurrences of "abc", "ab", "ac", and "bc", we iterate through the remaining characters in the word string. For each character that is not a placeholder ("-"), we increment the count by 2 to account for the necessary insertions.
4. Finally, we return the count as the minimum number of letters required to make the word string valid.
# Complexity
- Time complexity:
The time complexity of this solution depends on the size of the word string. In the worst case, we may need to iterate over the entire word string multiple times to replace occurrences of "abc", "ab", "ac", and "bc". Therefore, the time complexity is O(n), where n represents the length of the word string.


- Space complexity:
The space complexity of this solution is O(1) since we are not using any additional data structures that grow with the input size. We only require a constant amount of extra space to store the count variable and temporary variables for string modifications.


# Code
```
class Solution:
    def addMinimum(self, word: str) -> int:
        count=0
        while word.find("abc")!=-1:
            i=word.find("abc")
            word=word[:i]+"---"+word[i+3:]
        while word.find("ab")!=-1:
            i=word.find("ab")
            word=word[:i]+"--"+word[i+2:]
            count+=1
        while word.find("ac")!=-1:
            i=word.find("ac")
            word=word[:i]+"--"+word[i+2:]
            count+=1
        while word.find("bc")!=-1:
            i=word.find("bc")
            word=word[:i]+"--"+word[i+2:]
            count+=1
        for i in range(len(word)):
            if word[i]!="-":
                count+=2
        return count

```

solutions.content:
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n*3)$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(1)$$
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution {
public:
    int addMinimum(string s) {
        const string a = "abc";
        int n = s.size();
        int i=0;
        int ans = 0;
        while(i<n){
            int j=0;
            while(i<n and j<3){
                if(s[i]!=a[j]){
                    ++ans;
                    ++j;
                }
                else if(s[i]==a[j]){
                    if(i+1<n)++i,++j;
                    else{
                        ans+=2-j;
                        return ans;
                    }
                }
            }
        }
        return ans;
    }
};
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
To find what makes abc and its ab,bc,ac that makes abc in 1 additions
else all in 2 additions

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
first remove all present abc as they are not required
then count all ab,bc,ac

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(N)

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(1)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def addMinimum(self, w: str) -> int:
        w=w.replace("abc"," ")
        r=w.count("ab")+w.count("bc")+w.count("ac")
        k=w.count("a")+w.count("b")+w.count("c")
        return k*2-r*3
                    
            
```

# Approach
Two Pointer

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def addMinimum(self, word: str) -> int:
        
        target = "abc"
        i, j = 0, 0
        count = 0

        while i < len(word):
            if j == len(target):
                j = 0
            if word[i] == target[j]:            
                i += 1
                j += 1
            else:         
                count += 1
                j += 1
    
        count += len(target) - j
        return count
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
Need to find the correct sequence of letters, parse and correct errors where necessary. 

# Approach
Inspect from the end using a stack. 
Alternatively use deque for inspection from beginning. 

# Complexity
- Time/space complexity:
O(n), n = length of input


# Code
```
class Solution:
    def addMinimum(self, word: str) -> int:
        stack = list(word)
        result = 0
        while stack:
            for l in "cba":
                if stack and stack[-1] == l: stack.pop()
                else: result += 1
        return result
```

```
class Solution:
    def addMinimum(self, word: str) -> int:
        string='abc'
        count=0
        i=0
        if not word:
            return count
        count+=string.index(word[i])
        index=0
        while i<len(word)-1:
            index=string.index(word[i])
            next_index=(index+1)%3
            if string[next_index]!=word[i+1]:
                count+=1
                word=word[:i+1]+string[next_index]+word[i+1:]
            i+=1
        if word[-1]=='a':
            count+=2
        elif word[-1]=='b':
            count+=1
        return count
        


```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
check each letter and the letter before it, count missed letter in them, finally we got the answer
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
for better performance, I build a dict to count missed letter quickly, then check each letter, don't forget check the head and the tail
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:O(n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:O(1)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def addMinimum(self, word: str) -> int:
        mp={'aa':2,'ab':0,'ac':1,'ba':1,'bb':2,'bc':0,'ca':0,'cb':1,'cc':2}
        res=mp['c'+word[0]]+mp[word[-1]+'a']
        for i in range(1,len(word)):
            res+=mp[word[i-1:i+1]]
        return res
```

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def addMinimum(self, word: str) -> int:
        
        '''
        a -> a = 2
        b -> b = 2
        c -> c = 2
        a -> c = 1
        b -> a = 1
        c -> b = 1
        '''
        st = []
        p = 0
        for i in range(len(word)):
            if st and ord(st[-1]) == ord(word[i]):
                p += 2 
            elif st and ord(st[-1]) == ord(word[i])-2:
                p += 1
            elif st and ord(st[-1])-1 == ord(word[i]):
                p += 1
            st.append(word[i])
           
        if word[0] == 'b':
            p += 1
        elif word[0] == 'c':
            p += 2
        if word[-1] == 'a':
            p += 2
        elif word[-1] == 'b':
            p += 1
        return p




```

solutions.content:
# The Question Specific (and very bad) approach:
This is DSA's equivalent of hard coding in values and using "magic numbers". The solution is not scalable, and will fail at the smallest change of conditions. The values used here are specific to the constraints of this question, where the only three letters involved are "a", "b", "c". Even though solving for "b", "c", "d" should be the same, our solution will fail at it, or any other slightest change to the input type. 

These relations have been attained by drawing all the possible test cases on a notebook, and noting down the answers themeselves.

```
def add_minimum(word: str) -> int:
    n = len(word)
    if (first := word[0]) == "a":
        ans = 0
    elif first == "b":
        ans = 1
    else:
        ans = 2

    for i in range(1, n):
        if word[i] == word[i - 1]:
            ans += 2
        elif (word[i - 1], word[i]) in (("a", "b"), ("b", "c"), ("c", "a")):
            continue
        else:
            ans += 1

    if word[-1] == "a":
        ans += 2
    elif word[-1] == "b":
        ans += 1

    return ans

```

# Generic Approach:
This is a better and more sturdy solution to this problem. It is scalable, and will provide correct answers for any number of letters, starting from wherever in the alphabet, as long as all of them are in increasing order. We can adjust ```base``` to modify the starting letter, and pass in the number of letters that the string may have.

These equations have been attained by writing the test cases on a notebook, and finding the *general relations* between the input and the output, instead of directly noting down the answers.

We can further improve scalability by allowing letters to loop around after "Z", but I'll leave that as an exercise to you.

Eg- ```base = ord("a")``` with ```n_letters = 3``` will cover ```("a","b","c")```, whereas 
```base = ord("m")``` with ```n_letters = 5``` will cover ```("m","n","o","p","q")``` and so on.
```
def add_minimum_generic(word: str, base: str, n_letters: int) -> int:
    # Base is a mono-character string

    n = len(word)
    base = ord(base)

    ans = ord(word[0]) - base
    for i in range(1, n):
        if word[i] == word[i - 1]:
            ans += n_letters - 1
        else:
            ans += (ord(word[i]) + n_letters - ord(word[i - 1])) % n_letters - 1

    ans += base + n_letters - ord(word[-1]) - 1
    return ans
```


# Complexity
- Time complexity:
O(N), since we're iterating through the word just once.
- Space complexity:
O(1), since we're using constant space.

solutions.content:
# Intuition and Approach
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Keep track of the previous letter you saw and the current letter you're on. Based on the differnce between the previous letter and the current letter, add the necessary number of changes to a variable named count. 

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ --> 


# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def addMinimum(self, word):
        """
        :type word: str
        :rtype: int
        """

        prev = 'c'
        count = 0

        for l in word:
            if l == prev: count+= 2

            if l == 'a':
                if prev == 'b': count += 1
            if l == 'b':
                if prev == 'c': count += 1
            if l == 'c':
                if prev == 'a': count += 1

            prev = l


        if word[len(word) - 1 ] == 'a': count += 2
        if word[len(word) - 1 ] == 'b': count += 1
        
        return count
```

content.content:
Replace "abc" -> "0"
"ab" -> "1"
"bc" -> "1"
"ac" -> "1"
"a" -> "2"
"b" -> "2"
"c" -> "2"

and iterate over the new modified string and sum up all the digits.
Note: The order of replacing is the key
same problem\nHave you find the reason?
One of the most amazing question i solved on LC. Pure Logical, and the feeling of acceptance in one go is heavenly.
Did anyone try the LCS approach ? I know it will take O(N^2) , and there is a simple iterative method that works in O(N)
Can anyone tell me the thought process how he/she come up with a Solution.

If you want to be able to reliably derive a solution on sight without making lucky guesses or pattern recognition from similar problems, other thought processes like trying to recognize a pattern and then coding something up until it works won't cut it IMO. That would make it seem like you saw the problem before and turn the interview into essentially floundering around with intuition until you hopefully arrive at a solution in time. This is my thought process.
1) Realize the problem is an optimization problem over a decision space of exponential size (branching factor at least 3), and note that a search over the problem space implemented with a simple recursion with backtracking implementation will yield a correct, albeit exponential runtime.
2) Using your observation from #1, and your knowledge that greedy algorithms are often employed to efficiently optimize a set of decisions over even exponentially sized search trees, begin examining a set of 'localized' choices that might exhibit the Greedy Choice Property
3) Observe that every valid solution modifies the problem space to a string that begins with 'abc', therefore, the optimal solution must contain these set of localized steps. Can anyone tell me the thought process how he/she come up with a Solution.

If you want to be able to reliably derive a solution on sight without making lucky guesses or pattern recognition from similar problems, other thought processes like trying to recognize a pattern and then coding something up until it works won't cut it IMO. That would make it seem like you saw the problem before and turn the interview into essentially floundering around with intuition until you hopefully arrive at a solution in time. This is my thought process.
1) Realize the problem is an optimization problem over a decision space of exponential size (branching factor at least 3), and note that a search over the problem space implemented with a simple recursion with backtracking implementation will yield a correct, albeit exponential runtime.
2) Using your observation from #1, and your knowledge that greedy algorithms are often employed to efficiently optimize a set of decisions over even exponentially sized search trees, begin examining a set of 'localized' choices that might exhibit the Greedy Choice Property
3) Observe that every valid solution modifies the problem space to a string that begins with 'abc', therefore, the optimal solution must contain these set of localized steps. Use intuition to posit that one 'choice' (set of local decisions) we can make would be to minimally append either an a,b,c to each of the initial characters until we arrive at 'abc'. Perform a quick 'proof' by contradiction in your head to gain confidence that no optimal solution excludes this minimal set of decisions. You have identified a choice that satisfies the Greedy Choice Property
4) Realize that the Greedy Choice you have identified leads to a substructure decomposition which is also an optimal substructure (no surprise there, but good to check)
5) Using the 'choice' you have identified as satisfying both the Greedy Choice Property and resolving the problem to an Optimal Substructure (you need those two things to proceed with confidence that your algorithm will actually work) implement a greedy algorithm using a combination of iteration and/or recursion, and use LinkedList backed stacks are your data structure to demonstrate additional mastery of data structures
6) [Very Optional at best IMO] Further simplify the implementation by ripping out the linkedlist/stacks data structures, and any references to characters, by leveraging properties of ascii characters to achieve a slight constant time reduction in both runtime and memory, as well as LOC

we will interate word and check if expected letter is there or not according to repeating pattern of "abc" .if not present we increment count and increment and modulo index (we are adding a missing char to word)
Leetcode, why is the result for "aaaabb" 9? I think it\'s 6 because for 4 - a, 2 - b, 0 - c you need to add 2 "b" and 4 "c"

[a]bc [a]bc [a]bc  [ab]c  a[b]c :  As you can see the number of non-square brackets is 9 not 6. We add bc for first 3 \'a\' then we club 4th \'ab\' together and add \'c\' and for last \'b\' we add \'ac\' so in total we added 9 characters
You can\'t change the position of Characters.That\'s why bb also need 2a and 2c.

We need to make valid string for each char,

for 3 a's -> 2(bc) => 6,
next is ab -> 1 c => 1
and for last b -> 2(ac) => 2
so 9 is the ans

title: Find the Distinct Difference Array
question_content:
You are given a 0-indexed array nums of length n.

The distinct difference array of nums is an array diff of length n such that diff[i] is equal to the number of distinct elements in the suffix nums[i + 1, ..., n - 1] subtracted from the number of distinct elements in the prefix nums[0, ..., i].

Return the distinct difference array of nums.

Note that nums[i, ..., j] denotes the subarray of nums starting at index i and ending at index j inclusive. Particularly, if i > j then nums[i, ..., j] denotes an empty subarray.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [1,2,3,4,5]
Output: [-3,-1,1,3,5]
Explanation: For index i = 0, there is 1 element in the prefix and 4 distinct elements in the suffix. Thus, diff[0] = 1 - 4 = -3.
For index i = 1, there are 2 distinct elements in the prefix and 3 distinct elements in the suffix. Thus, diff[1] = 2 - 3 = -1.
For index i = 2, there are 3 distinct elements in the prefix and 2 distinct elements in the suffix. Thus, diff[2] = 3 - 2 = 1.
For index i = 3, there are 4 distinct elements in the prefix and 1 distinct element in the suffix. Thus, diff[3] = 4 - 1 = 3.
For index i = 4, there are 5 distinct elements in the prefix and no elements in the suffix. Thus, diff[4] = 5 - 0 = 5.

Example 2:

Input: nums = [3,2,3,4,2]
Output: [-2,-1,0,2,3]
Explanation: For index i = 0, there is 1 element in the prefix and 3 distinct elements in the suffix. Thus, diff[0] = 1 - 3 = -2.
For index i = 1, there are 2 distinct elements in the prefix and 3 distinct elements in the suffix. Thus, diff[1] = 2 - 3 = -1.
For index i = 2, there are 2 distinct elements in the prefix and 2 distinct elements in the suffix. Thus, diff[2] = 2 - 2 = 0.
For index i = 3, there are 3 distinct elements in the prefix and 1 distinct element in the suffix. Thus, diff[3] = 3 - 1 = 2.
For index i = 4, there are 3 distinct elements in the prefix and no elements in the suffix. Thus, diff[4] = 3 - 0 = 3.

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n == nums.length <= 50
  • 1 <= nums[i] <= 50

solutions.title: explained-using-map-very-simple-easy-to-understand-solution
solutions.content: Up vote if you like the solution # Approach Take two map, one to have the prefix indexed (mp) & second one is suffix indexed (rmp ). First evaluate the suffix mapping of all element by traversing and indexing all elements Then on second traverse start mapping the prefix index and removing the same from suffix mapping. - Need to erase the index if its occurance is zero. Take diff of the size of the maps & store in to the ans array. ``` vector distinctDifferenceArray(vector& nums) { vector ans; unordered_map mp, rmp; for(auto n: nums){ rmp[n]++; } for(auto n: nums){ mp[n]++; rmp[n]--; if(rmp[n] == 0) rmp.erase(n); ans.push_back(mp.size() - rmp.size()); } return ans; } ``` Here is an article of my last interview experience - A Journey to FAANG Company, I recomand you to go through this to know which all resources I have used & how I cracked interview at Amazon: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/3171859/Journey-to-a-FAANG-Company-Amazon-or-SDE2-(L5)-or-Bangalore-or-Oct-2022-Accepted

set-prefix-and-suffix
solutions.content:
First thought - The length of input is small. To find the number of distinct numbers, we can use Set. Therefore, we can iterate each number, put `nums[:i + 1]` and `nums[i + 1:]` to Set,  count the lengths and calculate the difference.

```py
class Solution:
    def distinctDifferenceArray(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        res = []
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            res.append(len(set(nums[:i + 1])) - len(set(nums[i + 1:])))
        return res
```

Here's the one-liner of the above solution.

```py
class Solution:
    def distinctDifferenceArray(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        return [len(set(nums[:i + 1])) - len(set(nums[i + 1:])) for i in range(len(nums))]
```

However, in above solution, it is not optimize as we slice the list for each index. To improve it, we can use prefix and suffix. The logic is similar. For each index, we add `nums[i]` in set and record the length. 

```py
class Solution:
    def distinctDifferenceArray(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        pre, suf = [], []
        ps, ss = set(), set()
        n = len(nums)
        for i in range(n):
            ps.add(nums[i])
            pre.append(len(ps))
        for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
            suf.insert(0, len(ss))
            ss.add(nums[i])
        # pre: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
        # suf: [4, 3, 2, 1, 0]
        # ans: [-3, -1, 1, 3, 5]
        return [pre[i] - suf[i] for i in range(n)]
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code

```
const distinctDifferenceArray = function (a) {
  const n = a.length
  const pre = new Array(n) // prefix counts
  const suf = new Array(n) // suffix counts
  let set

  set = new Set()
  for (let i = 0; i < n; i++) {
    set.add(a[i])
    pre[i] = set.size
  }

  set = new Set()
  for (let i = n - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
    suf[i] = set.size
    set.add(a[i])
  }

  const an = new Array(n)
  for (let i = 0; i < n; i++) {
    an[i] = pre[i] - suf[i]
  }
  return an
}
```

solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def distinctDifferenceArray(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:    #  Example:   nums = [3,2,3,4,2]
                                                                        #  
        pref, suff = defaultdict(int), Counter(nums)                    #   pref, suff = {}, {2:2, 3:2, 4:1}

        cur = -len(suff)                                                #  cur = -3

        for i, n in enumerate(nums):                                    #  n  cur  pref           suff           nums
            pref[n]+= 1                                                 # ––– –––  ––––––––       –––––––        –––––––
            suff[n]-= 1                                                 #      -3  {2:0,3:0,4:0}  {2:2,3:2,4:1}  [| 3, 2, 3, 4, 2]
            cur = nums[i] = cur + (pref[n] == 1) + (suff[n] == 0)       #  3   -2  {2:0,3:1,4:0}  {2:2,3:1,4:1}  [-2,| 2, 3, 4, 2]
                                                                        #  2   -1  {2:1,3:1,4:0}  {2:1,3:1,4:1}  [-2,-1,| 3, 4, 2]
        return  nums                                                    #  3    0  {2:1,3:2,4:0}  {2:1,3:0,4:1}  [-2,-1, 0,| 4, 2]
                                                                        #  4    2  {2:1,3:2,4:1}  {2:1,3:0,4:0}  [-2,-1, 0, 2,| 2]
                                                                        #  2    3  {2:2,3:2,4:1}  {2:0,3:0,4:0}  [-2,-1, 0, 2, 3|]
```

solutions.content:
# Code✅
```
class Solution:
    def distinctDifferenceArray(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        diff = []
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            prefix = len(set(nums[:i+1]))
            surfix = len(set(nums[i+1:]))
            diff.append(prefix-surfix)
        return diff
```

solutions.content:
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n)$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution {
public:
    vector<int> distinctDifferenceArray(vector<int>& nums) {
        unordered_set<int> s1, s2;
        vector<int> pre, suf(nums.size());
        int count = 0;
        // prefix array
        for(auto i : nums) {
            if(s1.find(i) == s1.end()) count++;
            pre.push_back(count);
            s1.insert(i);
        }
        // suffix array
        count = 0;
        for(int i = nums.size()-1; i > 0; i--) {
            if(s2.find(nums[i]) == s2.end()) count++;
            suf[i - 1] = count;
            s2.insert(nums[i]);
        }
        // ans;
        for(int i = 0; i < nums.size(); i++) {
            pre[i] = pre[i] - suf[i];
        }
        return pre;
    }
};
```

```
class Solution:
    def distinctDifferenceArray(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        n=len(nums)
        left=0
        right=n-1
        ans=[]
        while left<n:
            ans.append(len(set(nums[0:left+1]))-len(set(nums[left+1:right+1])))
            right+=1
            left+=1

        return ans    
```

```
class Solution:
    def distinctDifferenceArray(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        res =[]
        for num in range(len(nums)):
            prefix_num = len(set(nums[:num+1]))
            suffix_num = len(set(nums[num+1:]))
            res.append(prefix_num - suffix_num)
        return res
```

```
class Solution:
    def distinctDifferenceArray(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        res = []

        l = 0

        while l < len(nums):
            pre = len(set(nums[:l+1]))
            post = len(set(nums[l+1:]))
            res.append(pre-post)
            l += 1

        return res
        
```

solutions.content:
```
defmodule Solution do
  @spec distinct_difference_array(nums :: [integer]) :: [integer]
  def distinct_difference_array(nums) do
    mp = nums |> Enum.reduce(%{}, fn n, acc -> Map.update(acc, n, 1, &(&1 + 1)) end)

    nums
    |> Enum.reduce({[], %MapSet{}, mp}, fn n, {acc, st, mp} ->
      mp = delete(mp, n)
      st = MapSet.put(st, n)
      acc = [MapSet.size(st) - map_size(mp) | acc]
      {acc, st, mp}
    end)
    |> elem(0)
    |> Enum.reverse()
  end

  defp delete(mp, k) do
    mp = Map.update!(mp, k, &(&1 -1))

    if mp[k] == 0 do
      Map.delete(mp, k)
    else
      mp
    end
  end
end

```

```
  @spec distinct_difference_array(nums :: [integer]) :: [integer]
  def distinct_difference_array(nums) do
    mp = nums |> Enum.reduce(%{}, fn n, acc -> Map.update(acc, n, 1, &(&1 + 1)) end)

    nums
    |> Enum.reduce({[], %MapSet{}, mp}, fn n, {acc, st, mp} ->
      mp = delete(mp, n)
      st = MapSet.put(st, n)
      acc = [MapSet.size(st) - map_size(mp) | acc]
      {acc, st, mp}
    end)
    |> elem(0)
    |> Enum.reverse()
  end

  defp delete(mp, k) do
    mp = Map.update!(mp, k, &(&1 -1))

    if mp[k] == 0 do
      Map.delete(mp, k)
    else
      mp
    end
  end
end
```

solutions.content:
```
defmodule Solution do
  @spec distinct_difference_array(nums :: [integer]) :: [integer]
  def distinct_difference_array(nums) do

    len = length(nums)

    for i <- 0..(len - 1) do
      # Extract the suffix and prefix
      prefix = Enum.slice(nums, 0, i + 1)
      suffix = Enum.slice(nums, i + 1, len - i)
      # Determine a count of the distinct items in the prefix and suffix
      distinct_prefix_len = MapSet.new(prefix) |> MapSet.size()
      distinct_suffix_len = MapSet.new(suffix) |> MapSet.size()
      # The final line of an Elixir loop is a bit like a yield in Python
      # appending the result to some sort of internally generated
      # list which is finally returned to the caller.
      distinct_prefix_len - distinct_suffix_len
	  end
	end
end
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
The intuition here is simple, we will create two sets, prefi and suffix, and keep adding numbers accordingly and then finding the difference between there lengths.
We will see two approaches, one which is very basic and then the other how can we leverage python

# Approach
We will create an *ans* list and a prefix list since we will kepp adding the distinct numbers in prefix as we go ahead in array.

We will have two loops in the first approach, for each outer loop we will create an suffix list, in the inner list we will traverse the array for all elements to the right of index i for which we are calculating the and and keep adding distinct numbers in suffix list.

DO upvote if you like the solution!
 



# Code
```
class Solution:
    def distinctDifferenceArray(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        ans=[]
        prefix=set()
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            prefix.add(nums[i])
            suffix=set()
            for j in range(i+1,len(nums)):
                suffix.add(nums[j])

            l=len(prefix)-len(suffix)
            ans.append(l)

        
        return ans
                
        
```

# The second approach
Here too we are essentially doing the same thing just we are leveraging the use of python

```
class Solution:
    def distinctDifferenceArray(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        ans=[]

        for i in range(len(nums)):
            ans.append(len(set(nums[:i+1]))-len(set(nums[i+1:])))


        return ans
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
Here we need to obtain a resultant list which contains the values that it should be the count of the unique elements from the left side getting subtracted from the count of unique element from the right side.

# Approach
Declared a list with the length same as the length of the given list then iterate over the list and for each iteration we have the value of x as the element from beginning of the given list to the current index+1 because then only we will get the value beginning to the index after that y contains the values from index+1 to the end of the given list.These x and y should be a set to neglect the duplicate values from it.Finally append the difference between the length of x ad y.After the whole iteration return the rersultant list.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:O(n)

- Space complexity:O(1)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def distinctDifferenceArray(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        result=[]*len(nums)
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            x=set(nums[:i+1])
            y=set(nums[i+1:len(nums)])
            result.append(len(x)-len(y))
        return result
```

solutions.content:
![image.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/0f2778b5-beff-4c57-bf3d-10f0bc6eb620_1689931288.902618.png)


# Code
```
class Solution:
    def distinctDifferenceArray(self, nums: List[int]) -> List[int]:
        left = defaultdict(int)
        right = Counter(nums)
        ans = [0] * len(nums)
        for i, n in enumerate(nums):
            left[n] += 1
            right[n] -= 1
            if right[n] == 0:
                right.pop(n)
            ans[i] = len(left) - len(right)
        return ans
```

title: Maximum OR
question_content:
You are given a 0-indexed integer array nums of length n and an integer k. In an operation, you can choose an element and multiply it by 2.

Return the maximum possible value of nums[0] | nums[1] | ... | nums[n - 1] that can be obtained after applying the operation on nums at most k times.

Note that a | b denotes the bitwise or between two integers a and b.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [12,9], k = 1
Output: 30
Explanation: If we apply the operation to index 1, our new array nums will be equal to [12,18]. Thus, we return the bitwise or of 12 and 18, which is 30.

Example 2:

Input: nums = [8,1,2], k = 2
Output: 35
Explanation: If we apply the operation twice on index 0, we yield a new array of [32,1,2]. Thus, we return 32|1|2 = 35.

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= nums.length <= 105
  • 1 <= nums[i] <= 109
  • 1 <= k <= 15

explained-very-simple-easy-to-understand-solution
solutions.content: Up vote if you like the solution # Approach 1. Evaluate 2^k 2. Then calculate prefix & suffix bit wise value and store it 3. check each number by multiplying 2^k, if it has max ans or not. Q. Why this works : Ans : When we multiply a number by 2 then this equal to shifting the values to the left by 1 places. So to have a largest value we should shift a single number to the k number of times which end up with max value possible. now we don't know exactly which value to shift k times, so we check the same for all possible numbers and keep tracking the max value. # Code ``` long long maximumOr(vector& nums, int k) { long long ans = 0, mul = 1; vector pre(nums.size(), 0), suf(nums.size(), 0); pre[0] = nums[0]; suf[nums.size()-1] = nums.back(); for( int i = 1; i < nums.size(); ++i) { pre[i] = pre[i-1] | nums[i]; suf[nums.size() - i - 1] = suf[nums.size()-i] | nums[nums.size() - i - 1]; } for(int i = 0; i < k; ++i){ mul *= 2; } for(int i = 0; i < nums.size(); ++i){ long long x = nums[i]*mul; if(i-1 >= 0) x = x | pre[i-1]; if(i+1 < nums.size()) x = x | suf[i+1]; ans = max(ans, x); } return ans; } ``` Here is an article of my last interview experience - A Journey to FAANG Company, I recomand you to go through this to know which all resources I have used & how I cracked interview at Amazon: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/3171859/Journey-to-a-FAANG-Company-Amazon-or-SDE2-(L5)-or-Bangalore-or-Oct-2022-Accepted

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        cur = 0
        saved = 0
        for num in nums:
            saved |= num & cur
            cur |= num
        
        max_num = 0
        
        for num in nums:
            max_num = max(max_num, saved | (cur & ~num) | num << k)
        return max_num
        

```

solutions.title: prefix-suffix-detailed-explaination
solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        n, res = len(nums), 0
        pre, suf = [0] * n, [0] * n
        # calculate the prefix OR 
        for i in range(n - 1): pre[i + 1] = pre[i] | nums[i]
        # calculate the suffix OR
        for i in range(n - 1, 0, -1): suf[i - 1] = suf[i] | nums[i]
        # iterate each number
        # we apply k operations on nums[i], i.e. shift k bits to the left
        # why not applying on multiple numbers? 
        # first in binary format, multiplying a number by 2 is shifting 1 bit to the left
        # e.g. 0010 (2) -> 0100 (4)
        # e.g. 0101 (5) -> 1010 (10)
        # second, in OR operation, we wish there is a 1 as left as possible
        # which produces the greater value
        # hence, we apply on the same number to achieve the max value
        # which produces the max OR value
        # now we calculate nums[0] | nums[1] | ... | nums[n - 1]
        # by utilising the prefix OR and suffix OR
        # the reason is simple
        # we precompute the result instead of calculate the OR values on each iteration
        for i in range(n): res = max(res, pre[i] | nums[i] << k | suf[i])
        return res
```

solutions.content:
Here's the plan:
1. We determine the maximum number of bits for elements in`nums`.
2. We compile those elements in`nums`that have the maximum number of bits (`n`) in the array`cands`. (The answer will be determined by left-shifting one of these elements.)
3. We iterate through`nums`, keeping track of the bits seen (`bits`) and bits seen more than once (`extraBits`). 

4. We assess which element`c`of`cands`provides the *maximum or* after left-shifting`k`bits by: (a) xoring the bits of`c`from`bits`; (b) unioning the bits of`c << k`to`bits`to reflect the left-shifting of `c`; and (c) unioning the bits of`extraBits`to`bits`to replace bits incorrectly removed by the xoring. 

.
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:

        bits, extraBits, mx, cands = 0, 0, 0, []
        n = 1<<int(log2(max(nums)))                 # <-- 1)

        for num in nums:
            if num >= n: cands.append(num)          # <-- 2)

            extraBits|= num&bits                    # <-- 3)
            bits|= num                              #
            
        return max(bits^c |                         # <-- 4a)
                   c << k |                         # <-- 4b)
                   extraBits for c in cands)        # <-- 4c)
```
[https://leetcode.com/problems/maximum-or/submissions/952181068/](http://)

I could be wrong, but I think that time complexity is *O*(*N*) and space complexity is *O*(*N*).

# Code
```
from collections import Counter
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        counter = [0]*32
        for num in nums:
            for i in range(32):
                counter[i] += num & 1
                num = num >> 1
        res = 0
        for j, num in enumerate(nums):
            tmp = num
            for i in range(32):
                counter[i] -= tmp & 1
                tmp = tmp >> 1
            tmpres = 0
            for i in range(32):
                tmpres += (counter[i] > 0)*(1<<i)
            tmpres = tmpres | (num << k)
            res = max(res, tmpres)
            tmp = num
            for i in range(32):
                counter[i] += tmp & 1
                tmp = tmp >> 1
        return res
```

solutions.content:
I checked several solutions and created my own to see if I understood them correctly.
The idea is here to find number with the highest `bit_length` and save the value at `max_bit` and numbers at `max_bit_list`. Meanwhile also find bitwise OR for all other numbers ans keep them in `ans`.
Becuase we want the maximum bitwise OR we want to shift left numbers `k` times. Thus we shift every numbers from `max_bit_list` and keep total maximum of OR operation.

```
from operator import ior

class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        
        max_bit = 0
        max_bit_list = []
        ans = 0
        for n in nums:
            n_bits = n.bit_length()
            if n_bits > max_bit:
                max_bit_list.append(ans)
                ans = reduce(ior, max_bit_list)
                max_bit_list = [n,]
                max_bit = n_bits
            elif n_bits == max_bit:
                max_bit_list.append(n)
            else:
                ans |= n
        
        prefix = [0] * (len(max_bit_list))
        suffix = [0] * (len(max_bit_list))
        
        for i in range(1, len(max_bit_list)):
            prefix[i] = prefix[i - 1] | max_bit_list[i - 1]
        
        for i in range(len(max_bit_list) - 1, 0, -1):
            suffix[i - 1] = suffix[i] | max_bit_list[i]

        ans2 = 0
        
        for i in range(len(max_bit_list)):
            ans2 = max(ans2, ans | prefix[i] | max_bit_list[i] << k | suffix[i])
            
        return ans2
```

solutions.content:
# Approach
For every num in the nums array, we will multiply num by 2^k, and keep a track of the bitwise OR of all the array elements taken together. To perform this computation optimally, we keep a prefix and a suffix array.
    `prefix[i] = bitwise OR of elements at index 0 to i-1.`
    `suffix[i] = bitwise OR of elements at index i+1 to n-1.`

The reason why we are multiplying a single element by 2^k instead of multiple elements is simple. If we spread out the k over multiple elements, our max OR will not be multiplied by the most optimal multiplicative factor that it could have been.  

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(N)

- Space complexity: O(N)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:        
        pre = [0]
        or_val = 0
        for num in nums:
            or_val |= num
            pre.append(or_val)
        pre.pop()

        suf = [0]
        or_val = 0
        for idx in range(len(nums) - 1, -1, -1):
            num = nums[idx]
            or_val |= num
            suf.append(or_val)
        suf.pop()
        suf.reverse()

        max_or = 0
        for idx in range(len(nums)):
            num = nums[idx] << k
            prefix = pre[idx]
            suffix = suf[idx]

            max_or = max(max_or, num | prefix | suffix)

        return (max_or)

```

```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
```
```
        bitwiseOr = lambda x, y: x | y
        
        forward = list(accumulate(nums, bitwiseOr))
        backward = list(accumulate(nums[ : : -1], bitwiseOr))[ : : -1]
        
        forward = [0] + forward[ : -1]
        backward = backward[1 : ] + [0]
        
        res = 0
        
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            total = forward[i] | backward[i]
            t = nums[i] * pow(2, k)
            
            res = max(res, total | t)
        
        return res
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
The problem is find maximum value of or-operations to arr after apply at most k times multiply by 2 for any items in arr.
mutilpy 2 to a number means, the number double, also means add 1 bit to left in binary:
if 11001 after *2 got: 111001
we want maximum value that means we must got as much higher 1 bits as possible:
How? just select one number and multply 2 by k times, get longgest binary as possible
Why? if we use 2 numbers:a b, one increment x binary(x>0 and x<k), anther increment k-x binary, totaly not longger than just increment one of larger one
# so solution is try every item in nums, multipy it by pow(2,k), and | operate with other elements, record max-values so far.
# we can do or operations for array-elements in linear time, if we use prefixs and suffixs keep tracking:
eg if arr=[a,b,c,d]
prefixs[0]=a prefixs[1]=a|b prefixs[2]=a|b|c prefixs[3]=a|b|c|d
suffixs[0]=a|b|c|d suffixs[1]=b|c|d suffixs[2]=c|d suffixs[3]=d
so for value c in index 2:
f(c)=prefixs[1]|c*pow(2,k)|suffixs[2]
ans=ans(f(c),ans)


# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
    O(N)

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
    O(N)

# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def maximumOr(self, nums, k):
        """
        :type nums: List[int]
        :type k: int
        :rtype: int
        """
        def _shift(n,k):
            return pow(2,k)*n
        
        if len(nums)==1:return  _shift(nums[0],k)
        prefixs,suffixs=[0]*len(nums),[0]*len(nums)
        prefixs[0],suffixs[-1],ans=nums[0],nums[-1],0
        for i in range(1,len(nums)):prefixs[i]=prefixs[i-1]|nums[i]
        for i in range(len(nums)-2,-1,-1):suffixs[i]=suffixs[i+1]|nums[i]
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            if i==0:ans=max(ans,suffixs[i+1]|_shift(nums[i],k))
            elif i==len(nums)-1:ans=max(ans,prefixs[i-1]|_shift(nums[i],k))
            else:ans=max(ans,prefixs[i-1]|_shift(nums[i],k)|suffixs[i+1])
            
        return ans
```

solutions.content:
1. To maximize, we need to do all operations on a single number, and that number should have the highest length in its binary representation. We denote that length by `l`.
2. `prefix_or[i]` is the prefix or of `nums[:i]`, and `suffix_or[i]` is the suffix or of `nums[i+1:]`.
For every `a` in `nums`, if the binary of `a` has length `l`, we calculate the value and compare the value to `ans`, and keep the bigger one.
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        n = len(nums)
        prefix_or = [0]*n
        po = 0
        for i in range(1, n):
            po |= nums[i-1]
            prefix_or[i] = po
        so = 0
        suffix_or = [0]*n
        for i in range(n-2, -1, -1):
            so |= nums[i+1]
            suffix_or[i] = so
        
        l = len(bin(max(nums)))
        ans = 0
        for i, a in enumerate(nums):
            if len(bin(a)) == l:
                ans = max(ans, (a << k) | prefix_or[i] | suffix_or[i])
        return ans
solutions.code:
1. To maximize, we need to do all operations on a single number, and that number should have the highest length in its binary representation. We denote that length by `l`.
2. `prefix_or[i]` is the prefix or of `nums[:i]`, and `suffix_or[i]` is the suffix or of `nums[i+1:]`.
For every `a` in `nums`, if the binary of `a` has length `l`, we calculate the value and compare the value to `ans`, and keep the bigger one.
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        n = len(nums)
        prefix_or = [0]*n
        po = 0
        for i in range(1, n):
            po |= nums[i-1]
            prefix_or[i] = po
        so = 0
        suffix_or = [0]*n
        for i in range(n-2, -1, -1):
            so |= nums[i+1]
            suffix_or[i] = so
        
        l = len(bin(max(nums)))
        ans = 0
        for i, a in enumerate(nums):
            if len(bin(a)) == l:
                ans = max(ans, (a << k) | prefix_or[i] | suffix_or[i])
        return ans

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
We can consider calculating the final solution without modifying anything during the first pass. In the second pass, for each number X, we can remove the effect of that number, compute the effect of that number X multiplied by 2 "k" times, and record the running maximum.
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
In order the remove the effect of each number, we would need to know if there are any bits that show up more than once. (eg. 12 (1101) and 9 (1001) have repeating bits at first and last position. Hence, when trying to remove 12 from the total result, we need to ensure that the bits at 1001 are still there.)
# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(n)$$
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(1)$$
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        total = 0
        extras = 0 #bits that show up multiple times
        for num in nums:
            extras |= num & total
            total |= num

        res = 0
        for num in nums:
            original = total
            total -= num # remove bits of currrent number
            total |= num << k # add new number shifted k times
            total |= extras # add back "extra" bits that show up more than once
            res = max(res, total)
            total = original
            
        return res
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
- use count as dict to store 32 bit numbers
- as or operation need to use temp to deduct n as bits
- use greedy to brute force all cases, k use for one number is better for split to others
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(32 * n)
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(1)
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        # use count as dict to store 32 bit numbers
        count = [0] * 32
        # count all bit numbers
        for n in nums:
            for i in range(32):
                if n >> i & 1:
                    count[i] += 1

        ans = 0
        for n in nums:
            # as or operation need to use temp to deduct n as bits
            temp = count.copy()
            for i in range(32):
                if n >> i & 1:
                    temp[i] -= 1
                
            res = 0
            for i in range(32):
                if temp[i]:
                    res += 1 << i
            # use greedy to brute force all cases
            res |= n << k
            ans = max(ans, res)

        return ans
```

```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        nums=sorted(nums,reverse=True)
        cur = 0
        saved = 0
        for num in nums:
            saved |= num & cur
            cur |= num
        max_num = 0
        prev=0
        count=0
        for num in nums:
            count+=1
            max_num = saved | (cur^num) | num << k
            if(prev<=max_num):
                prev=max_num
            else:
                break
        return prev
```

python-simple-two-sweeps-explained
solutions.content:
A simple solution is just try every number of the array, compute the final OR value after shift the number `k` times to the left. During the process, we remember the maximum values and find the solution.

The problem becomes how to compute the OR value of the array efficently.
We can split the array into three sections:
* section 1: nums[0] ... nums[idx - 1]
* section 2: nums[idx]
* section 3: nums[idx + 1] ... nums[n]

If we know the OR value of section 1 and section 3, we can easily compute the final OR of the array.

**Sweep 1**: we compute the backward OR value of the array from last number to each index, this can help us know the OR value of section 3.

**Sweep 2**: we compute the forward OR value of the array from the first number to each index, and this helps us know the OR value of the section 1.

See the code below:

```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        n = len(nums)
        # backward sweep to compute the running OR from n-1 to idx
        backward_or = [0] * (n + 1)
        idx, ror = n - 1, 0
        while idx >= 0:
            ror |= nums[idx]
            backward_or[idx] = ror
            idx -= 1
        
        # forward sweep to get the OR value of the array if we pick nums[i] shifting k times
        ans, forward_or = 0, 0
        for i in range(n):
            t = forward_or | backward_or[i + 1] | (nums[i] << k)
            ans = max(ans, t)
            forward_or |= nums[i]
        return ans
```

```
        n = len(nums)

        backward_or = [0] * (n + 1)
        idx, ror = n - 1, 0
        while idx >= 0:
            ror |= nums[idx]
            backward_or[idx] = ror
            idx -= 1
        
        # forward sweep to get the OR value of the array if we pick nums[i] shifting k times
        ans, forward_or = 0, 0
        for i in range(n):
            t = forward_or | backward_or[i + 1] | (nums[i] << k)
            ans = max(ans, t)
            forward_or |= nums[i]
        return ans
```

solutions.content:
# Disclaimer
I wasn't able to crack this question during the contest; I figured out the trick but wasn't able to implement it nor rigorously prove why it works. Other solutions do a good job with the proof so I'll just explain my intuition down below.

# Trick
We want to find the maximal array OR (`nums[0] | nums[1] | ... | nums[n - 1]`), where we can multiply by 2 any values (possibly different ones) in the array, for a total of k multiplications. Immediately, because we're multiplying by 2 and trying to maximize a bitwise operation, we should realize that multiplying by 2 is equivalent to a single left shift.

It also turns out that it's best to select only one value to be shifted k times. This makes sense because, by shifting say the largest value k times, we can achieve a really big single value to be used in our array OR operation. However, choosing the maximum value in the array doesn't necessarily work (see the given example [12, 9]).

# Algorithm
A correct algorthm will do the following:
1. Figure out the candidates to be shifted (one pass)
2. For each number in the array (second pass)
  a. If the number is a candidate, do the below
  b. Compute the OR of the array, discluding the candidate; `curr_removed`
  c. Compute the candidate, shifted left `k` times; `shifted`
  d. Set the result to be the larger between the result and `shifted | curr_removed`

You'll notice that this approach would run in quadratic time since we're recomputing the array OR not including the candidate each time. Because the same bit can be included multiple times, we need to be smart about this, which is explained in the implementation.

# Implementation + Bithacks
Since we need to compute the array OR quickly and need only to simulate removing a single candidate, it makes sense to precompute this in a single pass for constant lookup later. However, it's not entirely clear exactly how to remove a candidate from an array OR from a first glance. If we re-think the array OR, we'll notice that it's equal to an OR of two components:

`array OR = bits_appearing_exactly_once | bits_appearing_two_or_more_times`

So, in our first pass that computes the candidates to be shifted, we can also compute the two bitsets as well (`once` and `two_or_more`).

Note that calculating the above bitsets can be done using only bit operations in an iterative way, for each number `curr = nums[i]`. Note that the order of how we're calculating `two_or_more` and `once` matters.

`two_or_more = two_or_more | (once & curr)`.
- Doing `two_or_more | ...` indicates we're keeping the current bits set two or more times, as desired.
- `once & curr` keeps bits that have appeared exactly once and are present in `curr`, which is equal to the bits that appear exactly twice within `curr`.

`once = ~two_or_more & (once | curr)`
- `~two_or_more & ...` means that we're using our updated `two_or_more` and making it so that any bits that are set in it **are cleared** in our computation of `once`
- `once | curr` simply tracks bits that had appeared once and possibly new bits present in `curr`.

With `once` and `two_or_more` computed, simulating the removal of a candidate from the array OR is more straightforward:
`array OR with candidate shifted = two_or_more | (once & ~curr) | (curr << k)`
- The bits in `two_or_more` are kept because removing of the bits in `curr` wouldn't have affected the presence of these bits when calculating the rest of the array OR
- `once & ~curr` keeps the bits appearing once while also simulating the removal of the bits set in `curr`
- `curr << k` left shifts `curr` the required number of times.

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        # maximumOr calculation: the best result should be the maximal value of:
        # OR(nums[i], i != j) | nums[j] << k, for each j. Not too sure why.
        # Compute bit counts efficiently in first pass      
        once, two_or_more = 0, 0 # track bits appearing exactly one time, bits appearing two+ times
        highest_bit = 0 # only need to promote the numbers with the highest bit set
        for curr in nums:
            highest_bit = max(highest_bit, curr.bit_length()) # track highest bit set using built-in bit_length
            two_or_more_next = two_or_more | ( # keep current two or more
                once & curr
            )
            two_or_more = two_or_more_next # things that have appeared 2+ times updated            
            once_next = ~two_or_more & ( # zero out things appearing two/more times using updated two/more
                once | # things that have appeared once are kept
                curr   # curr in binary = things that have appeared once
            )

            once = once_next

        # maximumOr calculation
        res = 0
        for curr in nums:
            if curr.bit_length() != highest_bit: # not a candidate for promotion
                continue
            shifted = curr << k
            curr_removed = once & ~curr # clear curr from once
            cand = two_or_more | shifted | curr_removed
            res = max(res, cand)

        return res
```

solutions.content:
**Idea**: Partial Sequence and Comparison 

`Multiplying a number y by 2` is equivalent to `adding a tailing 0 in its binary form`.
Therefore, we need to push the number with the most significant 1 bit as left as
possible by doing `y << k`. As there might be multiple numbers with the same most siginificant 1 bit, we need comparison.

In Eg-1, `12 = 1100; 9 = 1001`. The two numbers have the same most significant 1 bit position, 
that is the leading 1. So we compare the results by doing `12 << 1 and 9 << 1`.
Here it turns out the result yielded by doing 9 << 1 is larger: `30 = 11110`.
One can check the result yielded by doing `12 << 1 is 24 = 11001`.


In Eg-2, `8 = 1000, 1 = 0001, 2 = 0010`. The number 8 has the most significant 1 bit.
So we do: `8 << k`

Therefore, to get the maximal result, we just need to try doing `y << k` for each number in
the list, computing the corresponding bitwise OR result, and return the max of them.
To accelerate we could use prefix `OR` result and suffix `OR` result.

```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        
        # step-1 compute the prefix or and suffix or results
        n = len(nums)
        prefix_or = [0] * n
        prefix_or[0] = nums[0]
        suffix_or = [0] * n
        suffix_or[n-1] = nums[n-1]
        for i in range(1, n):
            prefix_or[i] = prefix_or[i-1] | nums[i]
        for i in range(n-2, -1, -1):
            suffix_or[i] = suffix_or[i+1] | nums[i]
        
        # step-2 comparison
        res = 0
        for i in range(n):
            pre, suf = 0, 0
            if i > 0:
                pre = prefix_or[i-1]
            if i < n-1:
                suf = suffix_or[i+1]
            res = max(res, pre | suf | (nums[i] << k)) # comparison
        
        return res
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition

try DP but got TLE :(
```py
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], K: int) -> int:
        n = len(nums)

        nums = [0] + nums
        dp = [[0]*(K+1) for _ in range(n+1)]
        
        res = 0
        for i in range(1, n+1):
            for k in range(K+1):
                for prevk in range(k+1):
                    dp[i][k] = max(dp[i][k], dp[i-1][prevk] | (nums[i]<<(k-prevk)))
                
        return dp[n][K]
```

the most important idea is that we don't need to try all possible operation set.

the optimal way is using all the operations to **one** nums[i].
then we just calculate every possible OR sum by doing `(nums[i]<<k) | nums[j]` where `0 <= j < n and j != i`. choose maximum as answer.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
$$O(n)$$

- Space complexity:
$$O(n)$$

# Code
```py
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], K: int) -> int:
        n = len(nums)

        prefix = [0] * (n+1)
        for i in range(1, n+1):
            prefix[i] = prefix[i-1] | nums[i-1]
        
        suffix = [0] * (n+1)
        for i in range(n-1, -1, -1):
            suffix[i] = suffix[i+1] | nums[i]

        res = 0
        for i in range(n):
            curr = nums[i]<<K
            
            # for j in range(i):
            #     curr |= nums[j]
            curr |= prefix[i]
            
            # for j in range(i+1, n):
            #     curr |= nums[j]
            curr |= suffix[i+1]

            res = max(res, curr)
        return res        
```

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, A: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        A.sort(reverse=True)
        res, left, n = 0, 0, len(A)
        right = [0] * n
        for i in range(n - 2, -1, -1):
            right[i] = right[i + 1] | A[i + 1]
        a=len(bin(A[0]))
        for i in range(n):
            if a>len(bin(A[i])):
                break
            res = max(res, left | A[i] << k | right[i])
            left |= A[i]
        return res
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach

- Time complexity:

<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums, k):
        n, max_val = len(nums), 0

        prefix, suffix = [0]*n, [0]*n

        prefix[0], suffix[n-1] = nums[0], nums[n-1]

        for i in range(1,n):
            prefix[i] = nums[i]|prefix[i-1]

        for i in range(n-2,-1,-1):
            suffix[i] = nums[i]|suffix[i+1]

        for i in range(0,n):
            temp = (1<<k)*nums[i]

            if i-1 >= 0:
                temp = temp|prefix[i-1]

            if i+1 < n:
                temp = temp|suffix[i+1]

            max_val = max(max_val,temp)

        return max_val
```

```
from functools import reduce
class Solution(object):
    def maximumOr(self, nums, k):
        """
        :type nums: List[int]
        :type k: int
        :rtype: int
        """
        op = []
        sub_nums =[]
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            a = nums[i]
            kk = nums[i]
            #print(a)
            #print(nums)
            for i in range(k):
                a *=2
            sub_nums = []
            for i in nums:
                sub_nums.append(i)
            if len(sub_nums)>0:
                sub_nums.remove(kk)
                sub_nums.append(a)
            bit_or = reduce(lambda x,y:x|y, sub_nums)
            #print(sub_nums)
            op.append(bit_or)
        if len(op)>0:
            return max(op)
        return -1


```

```
from functools import reduce
class Solution(object):
    def maximumOr(self, nums, k):
        """
        :type nums: List[int]
        :type k: int
        :rtype: int
        """
        op = []
        sub_nums =[]
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            a = nums[i]
            kk = nums[i]
            #print(a)
            #print(nums)
            for i in range(k):
                a *=2
            sub_nums = []
            for i in nums:
                sub_nums.append(i)
            if len(sub_nums)>0:
                sub_nums.remove(kk)
                sub_nums.append(a)
            bit_or = reduce(lambda x,y:x|y, sub_nums)
            #print(sub_nums)
            op.append(bit_or)
        if len(op)>0:
            return max(op)
        return -1


```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
You either multiply a given number by $2^k$ or you don't touch it.

# Approach
Compute prefix and suffix or of the array. The idea is that $\text{prefix}[i]$ is equal to $\text{nums}[0] \lor \text{nums}[1] \lor \dots \lor \text{nums}[i]$. You get the idea for the suffix array.

Then, iterate over all the numbers, the candidate solution for this index is given by:
$$\text{prefix}[i-1] \lor (2^k * \text{nums}[i]) \lor \text{suffix}[i+1]$$


# Complexity
- Time complexity: $O(n)$

- Space complexity: $O(n)$

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:

        def prefix_or(nums):
            prefix = [nums[0]]
            for e in nums[1:]:
                val = prefix[-1] | e
                prefix.append(val)
            return prefix
        
        prefix = prefix_or(nums)
        suffix = prefix_or(nums[::-1])[::-1]

        multiplier = 1 << k

        def f(i):
            v = nums[i] * multiplier
            p = 0 if i == 0 else prefix[i - 1]
            s = 0 if i == len(nums) - 1 else suffix[i + 1]
            return v | p | s

        ans = 0
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            ans = max(ans, f(i))

        return ans

```

```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:

        def prefix_or(nums):
            prefix = [nums[0]]
            for e in nums[1:]:
                val = prefix[-1] | e
                prefix.append(val)
            return prefix
        
        prefix = prefix_or(nums)
        suffix = prefix_or(nums[::-1])[::-1]

        multiplier = 1 << k

        def f(i):
            v = nums[i] * multiplier
            p = 0 if i == 0 else prefix[i - 1]
            s = 0 if i == len(nums) - 1 else suffix[i + 1]
            return v | p | s

        ans = 0
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            ans = max(ans, f(i))

        return ans

```

solutions.title: direct-computation
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
The problem is convex. It is always best to apply the operation (multiply one value on the list by 2) to just one value the maximum allowed number of times, that is k times.

The problem is determining which value. The first example in the statement of the problem shows that it does not have to be the largest value.

Since the number of items is at most $10^5$, it is enough to compute the potential answer in constant time for each.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
There are at most around 30 bits to consider, since $10^9 \sim 2^{30}$. For each bit, we record the total number of times it appears in some number on the list.
To compute the OR of all the numbers on the list except $nums_i$, we consider the total number of times each bit appears (which we only need to compute once), minus the number of times that bit appears in $nums_i$ (which can be 0 or 1). If after the subtraction it's still there, then it should appear in the OR.
Then we take the OR with $nums_i\cdot 2^k = nums_i<<k$. This is the candidate answer for $nums_i$. We compare all possibilities and select the largest.

Of course, this solution can be further optimized: for example, if a bit appears at least twice, then we don't need to perform the subtraction described above, because we know it'll still be there anyway.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $O(n)$.
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $O(n)$.
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        array=[0]*32
        lists=[]
        for n in nums:
            lst=[]
            while n:
                lst.append(n&1)
                n>>=1
            for i, l in enumerate(lst):
                array[i]+=l
            lists.append(lst)
        ans=0
        for i, n in enumerate(nums):
            array2=array.copy()
            for j, l in enumerate(lists[i]):
                array2[j]-=l
            s=0
            p=1
            for a in array2:
                s|=p if a!=0 else 0
                p<<=1
            s|=n<<k
            if s>ans:
                ans=s
        return ans      
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maximumOr(self, nums: List[int], k: int) -> int:
        left = [nums[0]] * len(nums)
        for i in range(1, len(nums)):
            left[i] = left[i - 1] | nums[i]
            
        right = [nums[-1]] * len(nums)
        for i in range(len(nums) - 2, -1, -1):
            right[i] = right[i + 1] | nums[i]
            
        ans = 0
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            l = 0 if i == 0 else left[i - 1]
            r = 0 if i == len(nums) - 1 else right[i + 1]
            ans = max(ans, l | (nums[i] << k) | r)
            
        return ans
        
```

content.content: Can someone explain why is it optimal to apply all the k operations on the same element? \nWhy isn\'t it possible, in some cases, to obtain a larger value for the bitwise OR of all the elements by distributing the operations on multiple elements?

[@daren](/daren) I looked at the description, thought a little, and started wondering how could this be a "medium" problem, as you can easily run into overflows and have many options to shift multiple numbers. Then I looked at the hints and they were "obviously wrong". Then I checked the discussions, which made me look at the signature, and I finally realized that the answer takes 64 bits. I feel that the description should have mentioned this and stand on its own, without you needing to check the signature. Am I wrong?
we will get left set bits

you only need to choose element which have left most set bit (so that you can left-shit that element k time and get max result), now you can get conflits like 9(1001) and 12(1100) and need to choose only one because once you perform left shift on it, it will be the left most set bit. So, now you need to perform rest (k-1) operation on that chosen element only.

You can solve this question with logic - (prefixOR | suffixOR | left most set bit elements * pow(2, k)) and take the max one.

i think it becomes obvious if they set the signature of the C++ function as:

long long maximumOr(vector \<long long\>& nums, int k)

otherwise its not clear, if you shift an int 15 times, does it become negative? do bits drop off the top end?

Hey [@Andrei Paval](/Andrei-Paval), I solved the problem using multiple operations on multiple numbers . The ans was still same and the time complexity is O(n * k). I think that greedily multiplying every number results in an optimal solution as multiplying a number by 2 ,k times will give a large result as mentioned by [@Aman Saini](/aman1320).
Multiplying single element k time will give more larger result.
[@Lee_fan_Ak_The_Boss](/Lee_fan_Ak_The_Boss) I want this power to get such kind of intuition.
Exactly, that is my doubt as well. Why can\'t I apply two operations to two different numbers?

you have to store prefix and suffix bitwise or operation at each index....and then not need to do k operation just take n = 2**k and mulitply n with each element of nums and perform the bitwise OR operation using stored sufix and perfix array...and Done it

The Reason behind applying all the k operations on the same element is
shifting
at each operation we are shifting and hence the number doubles so it is beneficial to double the maximum number at a point because it will increase the required output.

As soon as you applied the opeartion once on an element it will become double and you should keep applying the same operation on it again and again till k so that you can get maximum of it.
I hope you got it ! ❤️❤️
such a pain not come up with prefix solution...\nI used priority queue , passed the first few cases, and it failed...
can any one tell why it is applying the k operation on 1 index of example 1 means why not applying on 0 index if we are geting the maximum value 24+9=33
then we will get 25 only
you have to calculate OR of elements not sum of elements.. and 24 | 9 = 25
**Tricky one :)**\n\nI like it
why is the dp solution not correct?
[@heisenberg_44](/heisenberg_44) Just a guess!
[@heisenberg280](/heisenberg280) hehe you got good taste.how did you know i was indian?
Hamare naam k saath saath stats be aage piche hai :xD
New testcase nums=[974,816] k=2 cancelled my contest result. Ouch

However, I cannot understand why iterating k times and each time find the max OR result will yield wrong answer...

For example:
[10, 11], k = 2

The correct answer is to operate on 11.

But if we iterating 2 times:
At first time: 
operate on 10:
10100
  1011
--------
11111

operate on 11:
  1010
10110
-------
11110

Then we will choose to operate at on 10. And this will yield a wrong answer....

at each operation we are shifting and hence the number doubles so it is beneficial to double the maximum number at a point because it will increase the required output.

As soon as you applied the opeartion once on an element it will become double and you should keep applying the same operation on it again and again till k so that you can get maximum of it.

I can understand why we should apply all the k operations on the same element. 
However, I cannot understand why iterating k times and each time find the max OR result will yield wrong answer...

For example:
[10, 11], k = 2

The correct answer is to operate on 11.

But if we iterating 2 times:
At first time: 
operate on 10:
10100
  1011
--------
11111

operate on 11:
  1010
10110
-------
11110

Then we will choose to operate at on 10. And this will yield a wrong answer....

Can someone explain why is it optimal to apply all the k operations on the same element? \nWhy isn\'t it possible, in some cases, to obtain a larger value for the bitwise OR of all the elements by distributing the operations on multiple elements?

[@daren](/daren) I looked at the description, thought a little, and started wondering how could this be a "medium" problem, as you can easily run into overflows and have many options to shift multiple numbers. Then I looked at the hints and they were "obviously wrong". Then I checked the discussions, which made me look at the signature, and I finally realized that the answer takes 64 bits. I feel that the description should have mentioned this and stand on its own, without you needing to check the signature. Am I wrong?
we will get left set bits

you only need to choose element which have left most set bit (so that you can left-shit that element k time and get max result), now you can get conflits like 9(1001) and 12(1100) and need to choose only one because once you perform left shift on it, it will be the left most set bit. So, now you need to perform rest (k-1) operation on that chosen element only.

You can solve this question with logic - (prefixOR | suffixOR | left most set bit elements * pow(2, k)) and take the max one.

i think it becomes obvious if they set the signature of the C++ function as:

long long maximumOr(vector \<long long\>& nums, int k)

otherwise its not clear, if you shift an int 15 times, does it become negative? do bits drop off the top end?

Multiplying single element k time will give more larger result.

I feel that the description should have mentioned this and stand on its own, without you needing to check the signature. Am I wrong?
we will get left set bits

you only need to choose element which have left most set bit (so that you can left-shit that element k time and get max result), now you can get conflits like 9(1001) and 12(1100) and need to choose only one because once you perform left shift on it, it will be the left most set bit. So, now you need to perform rest (k-1) operation on that chosen element only.

You can solve this question with logic - (prefixOR | suffixOR | left most set bit elements * pow(2, k)) and take the max one.

i think it becomes obvious if they set the signature of the C++ function as:

long long maximumOr(vector \<long long\>& nums, int k)

otherwise its not clear, if you shift an int 15 times, does it become negative? do bits drop off the top end?

Hey [@Andrei Paval](/Andrei-Paval), I solved the problem using multiple operations on multiple numbers . The ans was still same and the time complexity is O(n * k). I think that greedily multiplying every number results in an optimal solution as multiplying a number by 2 ,k times will give a large result as mentioned by [@Aman Saini](/aman1320).
Multiplying single element k time will give more larger result.
[@Lee_fan_Ak_The_Boss](/Lee_fan_Ak_The_Boss) I want this power to get such kind of intuition.
Exactly, that is my doubt as well. Why can\'t I apply two operations to two different numbers?

you have to store prefix and suffix bitwise or operation at each index....and then not need to do k operation just take n = 2**k and mulitply n with each element of nums and perform the bitwise OR operation using stored sufix and perfix array...and Done it

The Reason behind applying all the k operations on the same element is
shifting
at each operation we are shifting and hence the number doubles so it is beneficial to double the maximum number at a point because it will increase the required output.

As soon as you applied the opeartion once on an element it will become double and you should keep applying the same operation on it again and again till k so that you can get maximum of it.
I hope you got it ! ❤️❤️
such a pain not come up with prefix solution...\nI used priority queue , passed the first few cases, and it failed...
can any one tell why it is applying the k operation on 1 index of example 1 means why not applying on 0 index if we are geting the maximum value 24+9=33
then we will get 25 only
you have to calculate OR of elements not sum of elements.. and 24 | 9 = 25
**Tricky one :)**\n\nI like it
why is the dp solution not correct?
[@heisenberg_44](/heisenberg_44) Just a guess!
[@heisenberg280](/heisenberg280) hehe you got good taste.how did you know i was indian?
Hamare naam k saath saath stats be aage piche hai :xD
New testcase nums=[974,816] k=2 cancelled my contest result. Ouch

I can understand why we should apply all the k operations on the same element. 
However, I cannot understand why iterating k times and each time find the max OR result will yield wrong answer...

For example:
[10, 11], k = 2

The correct answer is to operate on 11.

But if we iterating 2 times:
At first time: 
operate on 10:
10100
  1011
--------
11111

operate on 11:
  1010
10110
-------
11110

Then we will choose to operate at on 10. And this will yield a wrong answer....
