title: Lexicographically Smallest Palindrome
question_content:
You are given a string s consisting of lowercase English letters, and you are allowed to perform operations on it. In one operation, you can replace a character in s with another lowercase English letter.

Your task is to make s a palindrome with the minimum number of operations possible. If there are multiple palindromes that can be made using the minimum number of operations, make the lexicographically smallest one.

A string a is lexicographically smaller than a string b (of the same length) if in the first position where a and b differ, string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b.

Return the resulting palindrome string.

 

Example 1:

Input: s = "egcfe"
Output: "efcfe"
Explanation: The minimum number of operations to make "egcfe" a palindrome is 1, and the lexicographically smallest palindrome string we can get by modifying one character is "efcfe", by changing 'g'.

Example 2:

Input: s = "abcd"
Output: "abba"
Explanation: The minimum number of operations to make "abcd" a palindrome is 2, and the lexicographically smallest palindrome string we can get by modifying two characters is "abba".

Example 3:

Input: s = "seven"
Output: "neven"
Explanation: The minimum number of operations to make "seven" a palindrome is 1, and the lexicographically smallest palindrome string we can get by modifying one character is "neven".

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= s.length <= 1000
  • s consists of only lowercase English letters.

solutions.title: java-c-python-two-pointers
take-min-very-simple-and-easy-to-understand-solution
solutions.content: Up vote if this solution helps # Approach Take two iterator one from front and one from back. Then take the min of s(front) & s(back) and set both s(front) and s(back) to the min value. # Code ``` string makeSmallestPalindrome(string s) { int front = 0, back = s.size()-1; while(front <= s.size()/2){ s[front] = min(s[front], s[back]); s[back] = s[front]; front++; back--; } return s; } ``` Here is an article of my last interview experience - A Journey to FAANG Company, I recomand you to go through this to know which all resources I have used & how I cracked interview at Amazon: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/3171859/Journey-to-a-FAANG-Company-Amazon-or-SDE2-(L5)-or-Bangalore-or-Oct-2022-Accepted

class Solution:
    def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:    #  Example: s = 'sdnvnfe'

        ans, n = list(s), len(s)                        # n = 7 ,  n//2 = 3
                                                        #         ans = [s, d, n, v, n, f, e]
        for i in range((n+1)//2): 
                                                        #  i = 0: ans = [|e| ,d,n,v,n,f, |e|]
            ans[i]=ans[n-i-1] = min(ans[i],ans[n-i-1])  #  i = 1: ans = [e,|d|, n,v,n, |d|,e] 
                                                        #  i = 2: ans = [e,d,|n|, v, |n|,d,e]
     
        return ''.join(ans)                             #  return ().join([e,d,n,v,n,d,e]) = 'ednvnde'
```

solutions.content: ### Please upvote if you find this helpful. ✌ *This is an NFT* # Intuition The problem asks us to modify a given string `s` by performing operations on it. In one operation, we can replace a character in `s` with another lowercase English letter. Our task is to make `s` a palindrome with the minimum number of operations possible. If there are multiple palindromes that can be made using the minimum number of operations, we should make the lexicographically smallest one. # Approach 1. Convert the string `s` into a list of characters `s_list`. 2. Initialize two pointers `l` and `r` at the start and end of the list respectively. 3. Enter a while loop that runs until `l` is greater than or equal to `r`. 4. Inside the loop, check if the character at index `l` is smaller than the character at index `r`. 1. If it is, replace the character at index `r` with the character at index `l`. 1. If the character at index `l` is greater than the character at index `r`, replace the character at index `l` with the character at index `r`. 1. Increment `l` by 1 and decrement `r` by 1. 1. After the loop ends, join the list back into a new string `new_s` and return it. # Complexity - Time complexity: $$O(n)$$ where n is the length of string s. - Space complexity: $$O(n)$$ where n is the length of string s. # Code ``` class Solution: def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str: s_list = list(s) l,r = 0, len(s_list)-1 while l ord(s_list[r]): s_list[l] = s_list[r] l+=1 r-=1 new_s = ''.join(s_list) return new_s ```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
We are checking pairs of characters: `s[i]` and `s[-i-1]` and replace them with the lexicograficaly smaller one of them.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
`O(N)`

- Space complexity:
`O(N)`

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:
        pal=''.join([min(a,b) for a,b in zip(s[:len(s)//2],s[::-1])])
        return pal + s[len(s)//2]*(len(s)%2) + pal[::-1]
```
# Code explanation in Python
```
class Solution:
    def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:
        n=len(s)
        pal=''
        for a,b in zip(s[:n//2],s[::-1]):
            pal+=min(a,b)
        return pal + s[n//2]*(n%2) + pal[::-1]
```

```
class Solution:
    def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:
        before = 0
        after = len(s)-1
        l = [i for i in s]
        while before <= len(s)/2:
            l[before] = min(l[before], l[after])
            l[after] = l[before]
            before+=1
            after-=1
        return "".join(l)
```

class Solution:

        r,l,s=len(s)-1,0,list(s)

            else:s[l]=s[r]
            r-=1

<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach: Two Pointers
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n)$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$ 
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution {
public:
    string makeSmallestPalindrome(string s) {
        string ans = s; // because changing the given data is not good practice
        int i = 0, j = s.size() - 1;
        while(i < j) {
            if(ans[i] != ans[j]) {
                if(ans[i] < ans[j]) ans[j] = ans[i];
                else ans[i] = ans[j];
            }
            i++, j--;
        }
        return ans;
    }
};
```

        splt=[]

        slen=len(splt)
        j=slen-1

        strN=''

            i+=1
            j-=1
        string= "".join(splt)

solutions.content:
# Intuition
we're mirroring the string, changing 1 char at a time in order for it to be alphabetically smaller 

# Approach
creating an entirely new string is much faster than splitting the current one into a list and then joining it back

so we're just going to loop through the first half of the string, adding the smaller char between the current one, and its opposite on the other side of the middle point

We will then return the new string we've created, the middle char if the string has an odd number of chars, followed by the string reversed

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
$$O(n)$$

- Space complexity:
$$O(n)$$

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:
        ns = ""
        for i in range(len(s) // 2):

            # the right char is smaller, take it
            if s[i] >= s[-i - 1]:
                ns += s[-i - 1]
                continue

            # the left char is smaller
            ns += s[i]

        # odd number of chars, take the middle char into account
        if len(s) % 2:
            return ns + s[(len(s) // 2)] + ns[::-1]
        return ns + ns[::-1]
```

```
class Solution:
    def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:
        i = 0
        j = len(s) - 1
        while i < j:
            if s[i] != s[j]:
                 if s[i] < s[j]:                   
                    s = s[:j] + s[i] + s[j+1:]    
                 else:
                     s = s[:i] + s[j] + s[i+1:]        
            i+=1
            j-=1
                  
        return s
```

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:
        #use two pinter

        # comparer the char at the left and right index
        # if they are different, replace both chars with the 
        # smaller of the character

        #NOTE You cannot replace chars in a strings
        #so need to put the chatacters in a 

        #putting the chars from the string into an array

        sArr = []

        for char in s:
            sArr.append(char)

        lp = 0 #left pointer
        rp = len(s) - 1 #right pointer
        #changes = 0


        while lp <= rp: #can also be lp < rp
            if sArr[lp] != sArr[rp]:
                #changes += 1
                #if the characters are different
                # replace both chars with the smaller character
                if sArr[lp] < sArr[rp]:
                    sArr[rp] = sArr[lp]
                else:
                    sArr[lp] = sArr[rp]
            
            #move both lp and rp
            lp += 1
            rp -= 1
        
        #combining the array back into a string
        return ''.join(sArr)



```

defmodule Solution do
  @spec make_smallest_palindrome(s :: String.t()) :: String.t()
  def make_smallest_palindrome(s) do
    s = String.graphemes(s)
    t = Enum.reverse(s)

    Enum.zip(s, t)
    |> Enum.map(fn {a, b} -> min(a, b) end)
    |> Enum.join()
  end
end

```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

```
class Solution(object):
    def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s):
        """
        :type s: str
        :rtype: str
        """
        s = list(s)
        for i in range(len(s)//2):
            if s[i] != s[len(s)-1-i]:
                new = min(s[i], s[len(s)-1-i])
                s[i], s[len(s)-1-i] = new, new

        return ''.join(s)



```

# Approach
1. Split the characters of the string and compare with right end character to the left end and go on convering the two pointers. 
2. When you encounter a mismatch, replace the other character with the lexicologically lesser character.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
O(N)

- Space complexity:

# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s):
        i=0
        j=len(s)-1
        count=0
        word = list(s)
        while i <j:
            if word[i] != word[j]:
                if word[j] > word[i]:
                    word[j] = word[i]
                else:
                    word[i] = word[j]    
            i+=1    
            j-=1
        return "".join(word)    
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
1. first we have to think about that we have to make that string palindrome.
2. second whenever we think about palindrome we check with two pointer
3. when we are matching those two pointer and if they are not same and ascii value of first one is greater than second one then in this condition we replace first one with second one and vice versa

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
two pointer approach

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(n)

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:
        li=list(s)
        i=0
        j=len(li)-1
        while i<j:
            if li[i]!=li[j] and ord(li[i])>ord(li[j]):
                li[i]=li[j]
            else:
                li[j]=li[i]
            i+=1
            j-=1
        return "".join(li)
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s):
        s = list(s)
        i = 0
        j = len(s) - 1
        
        while i < j:
            if (s[i] != s[j]):
                if(s[i] > s[j]):
                    s[i] = s[j]
                else:
                    s[j] = s[i]
                    
            i = i + 1
            j = j - 1
            
        return(''.join(s))
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def makeSmallestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:
        letters = [letter for letter in s]
        i, j = 0, len(letters)-1
        while i < j:
            if ord(letters[i]) < ord(letters[j]):
                letters[j] = letters[i]
            if ord(letters[j]) < ord(letters[i]):
                letters[i] = letters[j]
            i += 1
            j -= 1
        return ''.join(letters)  
            
```

content.content:
Can someone please explain this case ??
```
input : s = "atie"
Output : "atta"
Expected : "aiia"
```
How can we connect `a` and `i` if they are not connected at the first place ?

Also if we consider a case where we can connect these letters, wouldnt be the smallest one be 
```
Expected : "aeea"
```

I think the key here is completing the task with "the minimum number of operations possible" and keeping it to be the "lexicographically smallest one" i.e. using the lowest letter values possible.

In the case that every letter is different in a string, the fewest operations we need to do are s.length / 2. We check first the outermost letters. If they match, great. No operation is needed. If they don't match, we need to set one of those letters to whichever letter is the lowest.

In the case of "atie" we first consider 'a' (first) vs 'e' (last).

Since 'a' is lower than 'e', change 'e' to 'a'. We now have "atia".

Then check the next pair of letters as we head towards the inside. This has us comparing 't' (second) vs 'i' (next-to-last).

Since 'i' is lower than 't', change 't' to 'i'. This results in "aiia".

"aeea" is not a possible outcome because 'e' only resides in the outermost pair of letters. So, it could never end up on the inside pair.
Think lexicographically using two pointers!

2 : element on ith ind is not equal to element on jth ind : in this case we are supposed to change any one of the element on ith or jth element so which we should change with whom to make string lexicographically smallest one, any guesses?

yes we will update the element which is larger among both the ind to the smallest element from both the ind and hence making the string lexicographically smallest one.

title: Extra Characters in a String
question_content:
You are given a 0-indexed string s and a dictionary of words dictionary. You have to break s into one or more non-overlapping substrings such that each substring is present in dictionary. There may be some extra characters in s which are not present in any of the substrings.

Return the minimum number of extra characters left over if you break up s optimally.

 

Example 1:

Input: s = "leetscode", dictionary = ["leet","code","leetcode"]
Output: 1
Explanation: We can break s in two substrings: "leet" from index 0 to 3 and "code" from index 5 to 8. There is only 1 unused character (at index 4), so we return 1.

Example 2:

Input: s = "sayhelloworld", dictionary = ["hello","world"]
Output: 3
Explanation: We can break s in two substrings: "hello" from index 3 to 7 and "world" from index 8 to 12. The characters at indices 0, 1, 2 are not used in any substring and thus are considered as extra characters. Hence, we return 3.

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= s.length <= 50
  • 1 <= dictionary.length <= 50
  • 1 <= dictionary[i].length <= 50
  • dictionary[i] and s consists of only lowercase English letters
  • dictionary contains distinct words

solutions.content: Up vote if you like the solution # Approach Simply we take each sub string and check if it is present in the dictionary or not. If present then move the index to ind + ith one do the recursion. Also we need to skip one elemnet and again do the check. This add up 1 to our value as we are considering that we are leaving the value. # Code ``` class Solution { public: unordered_set st; vector mem; int solve(string& s, int ind){ if(ind >= s.size()) return 0; if(mem[ind] != -1) return mem[ind]; int res = 1 + solve(s, ind + 1); //skip one element with vlaue 1 added to result for(int i = 1; ind + i <= s.size(); ++i){ //check if any of the chars can be skiped without any value returned string t = s.substr(ind, i); if(st.find(t) != st.end()) res = min(res, solve(s, ind+i)); } return mem[ind] = res; } int minExtraChar(string s, vector& dictionary) { mem.resize(s.size() + 1, -1); for(auto d: dictionary ) st.insert(d); return solve(s, 0); } }; ``` Here is an article of my last interview experience - A Journey to FAANG Company, I recomand you to go through this to know which all resources I have used & how I cracked interview at Amazon: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/3171859/Journey-to-a-FAANG-Company-Amazon-or-SDE2-(L5)-or-Bangalore-or-Oct-2022-Accepted

solutions.content:
![image.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/a2369537-e160-49ea-a79a-c3578dcff73c_1693632790.9550076.png)

# Intuition
**The problem requires breaking a given string s into non-overlapping substrings such that each substring is present in a given dictionary. The goal is to minimize the number of extra characters left over after breaking the string optimally.**
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
1. Initialize a defaultdict word_dict to store words from the dictionary grouped by their first characters. This helps in efficient lookup during string traversal.
2. Initialize a list result of length n+1 where n is the length of the input string s. This list will store the minimum number of extra characters left at each position in the string.
3. Iterate through the string s from right to left (starting from the end).
4. For each position i in the string s, calculate the minimum number of extra characters left if we break the string optimally at this position.
5. If the current character s[i] is found in the word_dict, iterate through the words that start with s[i] and check if they match the substring starting at position i. If a match is found, update result[i] with the minimum of its current value and result[i + len(word)], where word is the matching word.
6. Finally, return result[0], which represents the minimum number of extra characters left when breaking the string optimally.
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity

- Time complexity: $$O(n*m)$$, 
- where n is the length of the input string s, and m is the average length of words in the dictionary. In the worst case, we iterate through the string once and perform string slicing operations that can take O(m) time.
- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$ for the result list and $$O(m)$$ for the word_dict where m is the number of words in the dictionary.

# Code
```

from collections import defaultdict

class Solution:
    def minExtraChar(self, s: str, dictionary: List[str]) -> int:
        # Get the length of the input string 's'
        n = len(s)
        
        # Create a defaultdict 'word_dict' to store words grouped by their first characters
        word_dict = defaultdict(list)
        
        # Populate 'word_dict' with words from the 'dictionary' list
        for word in dictionary:
            word_dict[word[0]].append(word)
            
        # Initialize a list 'result' of length 'n+1' to store minimum extra characters at each position
        result = [0] * (n + 1)
        
        # Iterate through the string 's' from right to left
        for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
            # Initialize the current position in 'result' with one more extra character than the next position
            result[i] = result[i + 1] + 1
            
            # Check if the current character 's[i]' is found in 'word_dict'
            if s[i] in word_dict:
                # Iterate through the words that start with 's[i]'
                for word in word_dict[s[i]]:
                    # Check if the substring starting at position 'i' matches the current word
                    if s[i:i + len(word)] == word:
                        # Update 'result[i]' with the minimum of its current value and 'result[i + len(word)]'
                        result[i] = min(result[i], result[i + len(word)])
                        
        # Return the minimum number of extra characters left when breaking the string optimally
        return result[0]
#uncomment all the comments to save the memory
#Please Upvote if u like
```

# Complexity
- Time complexity: o(n^m)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(n)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minExtraChar(self, s: str, dictionary: List[str]) -> int:
        dictionary = set(dictionary)
        n,dp = len(s),[0]
        max_word_len = len(max(dictionary, key=len))
        for i in range(1,n+1):
            dp.append(dp[-1]+1)
            for j in range(i-1,max(i-max_word_len-1,-1),-1):
                if s[j:i] in dictionary:
                    dp[i] = min(dp[i],dp[j])
        return dp[-1]

        
```

solutions.content:
**Solution 1:**
```
class Solution:
    def minExtraChar(self, s: str, dictionary: List[str]) -> int:
        dp = [0] + [float('inf')] * len(s)
        for i in range(1, len(s) + 1):
            for w in dictionary:
                if s[i - len(w):i] == w:
                    dp[i] = min(dp[i], dp[i - len(w)])
            dp[i] = min(dp[i], dp[i - 1] + 1)
        return dp[-1]
```

**Explanation:**

Let's go through the solution step by step:

Initialize a dynamic programming (DP) array dp of length len(s) + 1 with all elements set to infinity except for the first element, which is set to 0. This DP array will store the minimum number of extra characters at each position i in the string s.

Iterate over each position i in the string s from 1 to len(s). For each position i, we will check if any word from the dictionary ends at this position.

Nested within the position loop, iterate over each word w in the dictionary. Check if the substring from i - len(w) to i in s is equal to the word w. If it is, this means we can form the word w using a substring ending at position i.

If we can form the word w at position i, update dp[i] to be the minimum of its current value dp[i] and dp[i - len(w)]. This means that if we can form the word w at position i, we can either continue the previous substring that ends at position i - len(w) or start a new substring at position i.

After iterating through all the words in the dictionary, update dp[i] to be the minimum of its current value dp[i] and dp[i - 1] + 1. This means that if we cannot form any word at position i, we have to add an extra character to the previous substring or start a new substring at position i.

Finally, return the last element of the dp array, which represents the minimum number of extra characters when breaking up s optimally.

The time complexity of this solution is O(N*M), where N is the length of the string s and M is the number of words in the dictionary. This is because we iterate over each position in the string s and for each position, we iterate over each word in the dictionary to check if it can be formed at that position. The space complexity is O(N) for the DP array.

**Solution 2**
```
class Solution:
    def minExtraChar(self, s: str, dictionary: List[str]) -> int:
        memo = dict()
        max_len = max(map(len, dictionary))
        dictionary = set(dictionary)
        
        def solve(i):
            nonlocal dictionary, memo, max_len
            if i >= len(s):
                return 0
            if i in memo:
                return memo[i]
            ans = float('inf')
            for j in range(i + 1, 1 + min(len(s), i + max_len)):
                ans = min(ans, j - i + solve(j))
                if s[i:j]  in dictionary:
                    ans = min(ans, solve(j))
            memo[i] = ans
            return ans
        return solve(0)
```

**Explanation**

The given solution implements a dynamic programming approach to solve the problem of breaking a string `s` into non-overlapping substrings from a given dictionary, while minimizing the number of extra characters left over.

Let's go through the solution step by step:

1. The solution defines a class named `Solution` with a method `minExtraChar` that takes in a string `s` and a list of words `dictionary` as input and returns the minimum number of extra characters left over.

2. The solution initializes a memoization dictionary called `memo` to store the results of subproblems. This dictionary will be used to avoid redundant computations and improve the efficiency of the solution.

3. The solution calculates the maximum length of a word in the dictionary using the `max` function and the `map` function with the `len` function applied to each word in the dictionary.

4. The `dictionary` list is converted into a set called `dictionary` to improve the lookup time for words in subsequent steps.

5. The solution defines an inner helper function called `solve`, which takes an index `i` as input and returns the minimum number of extra characters left over starting from index `i`.

6. Inside the `solve` function, the first base case is checked. If the index `i` is already beyond the length of the string `s`, it means we have processed the entire string, so we return 0 (no extra characters left over).

7. The second base case checks if the result for the current index `i` is already stored in the `memo` dictionary. If it is, we return the precalculated result to avoid redundant computations.

8. If the base cases are not met, the solution initializes a variable `ans` with a value of positive infinity (float('inf')). This variable will be used to store the minimum number of extra characters left over for the current index `i`.

9. The solution then enters a loop that iterates from `i + 1` to the minimum of `len(s)` and `i + max_len + 1`. This loop represents all possible substrings starting from index `i` with lengths ranging from 1 to `max_len`.

10. Within the loop, the solution updates the `ans` variable to the minimum value between the current `ans` and the difference `j - i` (representing the length of the current substring) plus the result of the recursive call to `solve(j)`. This line evaluates the possibility of breaking the string at index `j` and recursively solving the subproblem for the remaining substring.

11. The solution then checks if the substring `s[i:j]` is present in the `dictionary` set. If it is, it updates the `ans` variable to the minimum value between the current `ans` and the result of the recursive call to `solve(j)`. This line evaluates the possibility of not breaking the string at index `j` and directly continuing from index `j` without any extra characters left over.

12. Finally, the `ans` value is stored in the `memo` dictionary for the current index `i` and returned as the result.

13. Outside the `solve` function, the `minExtraChar` method is called with an initial index of 0, representing the start of the string.

14. The result of the `solve` method is returned as the final output of the `minExtraChar` method.

Overall, the solution uses memoization and recursive calls to efficiently explore all possible substrings and find the minimum number of extra characters left over by breaking the string optimally based on the given dictionary.

**The time complexity** of the provided solution is exponential, specifically O(2^n), where n is the length of the input string s.

The exponential time complexity arises due to the recursive nature of the solution. In the solve function, for each index i, the function explores all possible substrings starting from i+1 to i+max_len. This leads to a branching factor of approximately max_len at each recursive call. Since the function can be called multiple times for each index, the total number of function calls grows exponentially with the length of the string.

Moreover, the solution uses memoization to store and retrieve previously computed results, which helps avoid redundant computations. However, in the worst case, where no memoized results are available, the solution still explores all possible combinations of substrings, resulting in exponential time complexity.

It's worth noting that the exponential time complexity is inevitable for this problem because the solution needs to explore all possible combinations of substrings to find the optimal solution.

# Python | Easy to Understand | Explained 
```
from collections import defaultdict

class Solution:
    def minExtraChar(self, s: str, dictionary: List[str]) -> int:
        # Get the length of the input string 's'
        n = len(s)
        
        # Create a defaultdict 'word_dict' to store words grouped by their first characters
        word_dict = defaultdict(list)
        
        # Populate 'word_dict' with words from the 'dictionary' list
        for word in dictionary:
            word_dict[word[0]].append(word)
            
        # Initialize a list 'result' of length 'n+1' to store minimum extra characters at each position
        result = [0] * (n + 1)
        
        # Iterate through the string 's' from right to left
        for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
            # Initialize the current position in 'result' with one more extra character than the next position
            result[i] = result[i + 1] + 1
            
            # Check if the current character 's[i]' is found in 'word_dict'
            if s[i] in word_dict:
                # Iterate through the words that start with 's[i]'
                for word in word_dict[s[i]]:
                    # Check if the substring starting at position 'i' matches the current word
                    if s[i:i + len(word)] == word:
                        # Update 'result[i]' with the minimum of its current value and 'result[i + len(word)]'
                        result[i] = min(result[i], result[i + len(word)])
                        
        # Return the minimum number of extra characters left when breaking the string optimally
        return result[0]
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
For each character in s, you loop all words and all characters in dictionary  to find if a certain word can be taken. Evaluate by using tc, tc would be 50 x 50 x 50 = 125_000 -> Possible.

# Approach
Top down dp

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
O(sdw) -> double loop with word slicing

- Space complexity:
O(s) -> dp cache size

s = len(s)
d = len(dictionary)
w = average length of words in dictionary

# Code
```
import collections

class Solution:
    def minExtraChar(self, s: str, dictionary: List[str]) -> int:
        @cache
        def dp(i): # return int, min delete
            if i == len(s):
                return 0
            
            res = float('inf')

            # take s[i]
            for word in dictionary:
                if len(word) + i > len(s): # word too long
                    continue
                
                sub_s = s[i: i + len(word)]
                
                # can take word
                if sub_s == word:
                    res = min(res, dp(i + len(word)))

            # skip s[i]
            res = min(res, dp(i + 1) + 1)

            return res

        return dp(0)
```

solutions.content:
# Approach
1. Create an array `max` to act as a hash table.
2. Create recursive function `f` which takes parameter index `i`. In it:
    1. If `s[i]` does not exist, return `0`.
    2. If a hashed value exists at `max[i]`, return `max[i]`.
    3. Iterate through dictionary. For each entry `word`:
        1. If `word` equals to the substring of `s` from index `i` to `i + word.length`, set `max[i] = max( max[i], word.length + f( i + word.length )`.
    4. Return `max[i] = max( max[i], f( i + 1 ) )`.
1. Return `s.length - f(0)`. 

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(ns)$$
- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$

Where $n$ is length of `dictionary` & $s$ is the aggregate character length of all strings i.

# Code
```
const minExtraChar = ( s, dictionary ) => {
    let max = [], f = i => {
        if ( !s[i] ) return 0
        if ( max[i] ) return max[i]
        for ( let word of dictionary )
            if ( s.substring( i, i+word.length ) == word )
                max[i] = Math.max( ~~max[i], word.length+f( i+word.length ) )
        return max[i] = Math.max( ~~max[i], f( i+1 ) )
    }
    return s.length - f(0)
}
```

from collections import defaultdict

class Solution:
    def minExtraChar(self, s: str, dictionary: List[str]) -> int:
        n = len(s)
        
        # comments are generated by chatGPT
        # Create a defaultdict to group words by their starting letter
        word_dict = defaultdict(list)
        for word in dictionary:
            word_dict[word[0]].append(word)
            
        # Initialize DP array to hold the minimum extra characters needed from i to end
        dp = [0] * (n+1)
        
        # Iterate through the string from end to start
        for i in range(n-1, -1, -1):
            # In the worst case, we can choose not to use the current character,
            # hence one extra character will be there
            dp[i] = dp[i+1] + 1  
            
            # Check if there are any words that start with this character
            if s[i] in word_dict:
                # If yes, try each word and update the DP array
                for word in word_dict[s[i]]:
                    if s[i:i+len(word)] == word:
                        dp[i] = min(dp[i], dp[i+len(word)])
                        
        return dp[0]
```

solutions.content:
If you're comfortable with dynamic programming, this problem is an interesting challenge.  It took some thought to determine how to fit this problem into an iterative dp framework.

# Approach
To start, create the dp array.  This solution are creates an empty string, which will be added to as we traverse the input string and test if characters can be removed.

The main loop iterates through the string.  Append that character to the test string, and add 1 to the previous dp value, as this new character will be remaining.  For each character in the string, this solution iterates through each dictionary array value, and tests if the test string ends with that dictionary value.  If it does, backtrack in the dp array by the length of that dictionary word, and compare to the current dp index, taking the minimum of all options, which will be the optimal choice of all dictionary options to remove.

Once the full string is traversed, the last value in dp will be the minimum remaining characters after optimal usage of the dictionary word removal.

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minExtraChar(self, s: str, dictionary: List[str]) -> int:
        n = len(s)
        dp = [0] * (n+1)
        teststr = ""
        for i, c in enumerate(s):
            teststr += c
            newdp = dp[i] + 1
            for d in dictionary:
                backtrack = len(d)
                if teststr.endswith(d):
                    newdp = min(newdp, dp[i-backtrack+1])
            dp[i+1] = newdp
        
        return dp[-1]
```

class Solution:
    def minExtraChar(self, s: str, dictionary: List[str]) -> int:
        def dfs(cur, k):
            if k >= self.Min: # no need to keep searching
                return
            if cur == n: # save current answer
                self.Min = min(self.Min, k)
                return
            for i in range(cur, n):
                if s[cur:i+1] in d: # if match, jump to this word's end-index + 1
                    dfs(i+1, k)
            dfs(cur+1, k+1) # skip index cur, so k+1
            
        d = set(dictionary)
        n = len(s)
        self.Min = inf
        dfs(0, 0)
        return self.Min
```

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minExtraChar(self, s: str, dictionary: List[str]) -> int:
        diction = set(dictionary)
        n = len(s)
        dp = [0] * (n + 1)

        for i in range(1, n + 1):
            dp[i] = dp[i - 1] + 1
            for j in range(i - 1, -1, -1):
                if s[j: i] in diction:
                    dp[i] = min(dp[i], dp[j])

        return dp[n]
                
        
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
Extension of Word Break


# Approach
1.  dp = [51] * (len(s) + 1)  since 50 char only so keep this no highest
2. empty string has 0 extra char
3. new substring will have  old substring +1 as the len of extra char (worst case)
4. now loop through dict check the match, and change the dp[i]; 
Note: Mostly a string is matches we do at i . dp[i-1]+1 or dp[i] >= dp[i - len(word)] # i- len(word)at the staring of the word
 
# Complexity
- Time complexity:
O(N * M) [N is the length of the input string s, and M is the total number of characters in the dictionary.]

- Space complexity:
O(N + M) [N is the length of the input string s, and M is the total number of characters in the dictionary.]

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minExtraChar(self, s: str, dictionary: List[str]) -> int:
   
        dictionary_set = set(dictionary)
        dp = [51] * (len(s) + 1) #since len(s)<=50
        dp[0] = 0  # No extra characters for an empty string
        
        for i in range(1, len(s) + 1):
            dp[i]=dp[i-1]+1
            for word in dictionary_set:
                if i - len(word) >= 0 and s[i - len(word):i] == word:
                    dp[i] = min(dp[i], dp[i - len(word)] )
        
        # The final result is the minimum number of extra characters at the end of the string
        return dp[-1]

```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
The goal of this problem is to find the minimum number of characters that remain in a string after removing words from that string using a dictionary. 

If the dictionary words don't overlap, the solution is easy. In the example
 `'leetscode'`, the dictionary `['leet', 'code']` removes all letters save for `s`. Therefore the answer is 1. 

If we make a toy example, such as `changer` with dictionary `['chan','hanger']`, if `chan` is stricken from `changer`, then remaining string no longer contains `hanger`. So-`hanger` must be removed because it removes more letters leaving fewer characters in the string, resulting in an answer `1`. 

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
My approach is dynamic programming. We get the length of the string. Turn the dictionary (which is really a list of words) into a set because a set has `O(1)` lookup time. We initialize the array to store the up-to-date minimum number of characters with each iteration. 

Iterate over the whole list of characters in the input string, `s`. Start at `index=1` because the memo array is one item longer than the length of the string, in order to initialize the search at `0`. 

If the current character at step `i` is not found in any dictionary word, then the count of letters goes up and `dp[i] = dp[i-1] + 1`. The list `dp` at index `i` adds `1` to the entry previous index `i-1`. 

Next, we check if the the current letter at `i` is part of a word in the dictionary. Loop for all the possibilities from `1` to `i+1` exclusive. Let the variable be `ell`, and the max value of `ell=i`. The nested loop looks back on the visited characters to see if a new word may be found. 

With the loop, we can split the string and check the dictionary words. The slice is `s[i-ell:i]`, where `ell` is incrementing with in the nested loop. Note the lowest `ell` can be is 1, so the slice always has a length of at least 1. 

If a substring matches a word in the dictionary, update the list `dp[i]` at index `i` with the minimum of either the current character count, which has already been incremented by 1 to accomodate the current character, or `dp[i-ell]`. The list `dp` holds in memory the minimum number of characters at every index of the input string. If we can remove a word because the substring is in the dictionary, we do not need to add a character to `dp`, nor do we need to include any characters included in the word. We do need to take the minimum of the current `dp[i]` versus `dp[i-ell]` for the problem of **overlapping words**. It may be that `dp[i]` is smaller than `dp[i-ell]` despite the word being found in the dictionary. 

In the end, return the last entry in the list `dp`. The last entry accomodates the entire string and has minimized the number of characters. 


# Complexity
- Time complexity: 212 ms
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: 16.24 MB
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minExtraChar(self, s: str, dictionary: List[str]) -> int:
        n = len(s)
        dictionary_set = set(dictionary)
        dp = [0] * (len(s) + 1)

        for i in range(1, len(s) + 1):
            dp[i] = dp[i - 1] + 1
            for ell in range(1, i+1):
                if s[i-ell:i] in dictionary_set:
                    dp[i] = min(dp[i], dp[i-ell])
                     
        return dp[-1]
```

Hint:

We know that substring of `s` must exist in dictionary to be able to break. The substring may start from index 0. If it doesn't then the index 0 is the leftover and so on.

More generally, for every substring there are a 2 choices:

1) this substring is an leftover then `len(substring) + mininmumLeftOver(rest of the string)`
 2) this substring is part of a substring of string from dictionary, then `0(no leftover) + mininmumLeftOver(rest of the string)`. 

We shall pick the minimum from these 2 choices.
Knapsack  problem

Hint:

We know that substring of `s` must exist in dictionary to be able to break. The substring may start from index 0. If it doesn't then the index 0 is the leftover and so on.

More generally, for every substring there are a 2 choices:

1) this substring is an leftover then `len(substring) + mininmumLeftOver(rest of the string)`
 2) this substring is part of a substring of string from dictionary, then `0(no leftover) + mininmumLeftOver(rest of the string)`. 

We shall pick the minimum from these 2 choices.
Knapsack  problem

```
azvzulhlwxwobowijiyebeaskecvtjqwkmaqnvnaomaqnvf
azv
   zul
    u
          wobow
            b
               i
                 i
                  yeb
                    b
                        kecv
                                 maqnv
                                    n
                                      na
                                      n
                                         maqnv
                                            n
```
With `15` extra characters you can produce this:
```
azv zul _ _ _ _ wobow i _ i yeb _ _ _ kecv _ _ _ _ _ maqnv na _ maqnv _
```

Hint:

We know that substring of `s` must exist in dictionary to be able to break. The substring may start from index 0. If it doesn't then the index 0 is the leftover and so on.

More generally, for every substring there are a 2 choices:

1) this substring is an leftover then `len(substring) + mininmumLeftOver(rest of the string)`
 2) this substring is part of a substring of string from dictionary, then `0(no leftover) + mininmumLeftOver(rest of the string)`. 

We shall pick the minimum from these 2 choices.
Knapsack  problem

```
azvzulhlwxwobowijiyebeaskecvtjqwkmaqnvnaomaqnvf
azv
   zul
    u
          wobow
            b
               i
                 i
                  yeb
                    b
                        kecv
                                 maqnv
                                    n
                                      na
                                      n
                                         maqnv
                                            n
```
With `15` extra characters you can produce this:
```
azv zul _ _ _ _ wobow i _ i yeb _ _ _ kecv _ _ _ _ _ maqnv na _ maqnv _
```

Hint:

We know that substring of `s` must exist in dictionary to be able to break. The substring may start from index 0. If it doesn't then the index 0 is the leftover and so on.

More generally, for every substring there are a 2 choices:

1) this substring is an leftover then `len(substring) + mininmumLeftOver(rest of the string)`
 2) this substring is part of a substring of string from dictionary, then `0(no leftover) + mininmumLeftOver(rest of the string)`. 

We shall pick the minimum from these 2 choices.
Knapsack  problem

```
azvzulhlwxwobowijiyebeaskecvtjqwkmaqnvnaomaqnvf
azv
   zul
    u
          wobow
            b
               i
                 i
                  yeb
                    b
                        kecv
                                 maqnv
                                    n
                                      na
                                      n
                                         maqnv
                                            n
```
With `15` extra characters you can produce this:
```
azv zul _ _ _ _ wobow i _ i yeb _ _ _ kecv _ _ _ _ _ maqnv na _ maqnv _
```

Hint:

We know that substring of `s` must exist in dictionary to be able to break. The substring may start from index 0. If it doesn't then the index 0 is the leftover and so on.

More generally, for every substring there are a 2 choices:

1) this substring is an leftover then `len(substring) + mininmumLeftOver(rest of the string)`
 2) this substring is part of a substring of string from dictionary, then `0(no leftover) + mininmumLeftOver(rest of the string)`. 

We shall pick the minimum from these 2 choices.
Knapsack  problem

```
azvzulhlwxwobowijiyebeaskecvtjqwkmaqnvnaomaqnvf
azv
   zul
    u
          wobow
            b
               i
                 i
                  yeb
                    b
                        kecv
                                 maqnv
                                    n
                                      na
                                      n
                                         maqnv
                                            n
```
With `15` extra characters you can produce this:
```
azv zul _ _ _ _ wobow i _ i yeb _ _ _ kecv _ _ _ _ _ maqnv na _ maqnv _
```

Hint:

We know that substring of `s` must exist in dictionary to be able to break. The substring may start from index 0. If it doesn't then the index 0 is the leftover and so on.

More generally, for every substring there are a 2 choices:

1) this substring is an leftover then `len(substring) + mininmumLeftOver(rest of the string)`
 2) this substring is part of a substring of string from dictionary, then `0(no leftover) + mininmumLeftOver(rest of the string)`. 

We shall pick the minimum from these 2 choices.
Knapsack  problem

`Tips:-`

This is the `cutting` type dp problem where inside the recursive function, you will have to iterate through each of the index and decide the optimal position to cut.

At each cut, you will be adding a char to your current String and then you will have to call the function again.

When you cut, check whether the `currString` is in dictionary or not, if it is, it does not contribute to any extra character, but if it's not, then it's contribution will be its`length`.

Then, count the future extras by calling the function again, at then end, find the `minimum` of `currExtra+futuExtra` for all possible cut positions

How do we define " non-overlapping substrings" for this task? Are "abc" and "bcd" overlapping? are "bad" and "a" overlapping? Or should one string be inside another to be overlapping? Or should their ends have common sequences?
In `"abcd"` -> `"abc"` & `"bcd"` are overlapping, while\nIn `"abcbcd"` -> `"abc"` & `"bcd"` are not overlapping.

I spent a long time thinking that each word in dictionary can only be used once at most. I was very confused how this wasn\'t considered a hard problem. Pro tip: Thats not the case, each substring has to be a word in the dictionary, but they dont have to be different words.

I think I may have found an error in test case number 1991. When using regex on the entire dictionary, sorting the words in descending order and simply replacing all matches with an empty string, my solution gives a minimum number of extra characters of 14, while the solution states it\'s 15, which makes no sense to me, since if my solution should be wrong, my minimum remaining character should be HIGHER than the solution and not LOWER. Is there any way how I can report this testcase as I think it is wrong?
Take the test case:\n"abcde",["ae","bcd"]\nYou would remove bcd and suddenly you have ae which also matches.

Here are the words of the `dictionary` as they appear in `s`:
```
aakodubkrlauvfkzje
 ak
  kod
   od
        rl
        r
            vfk
            v
```
With `9` extra characters you can produce this:
```
_ ak od _ _ _ rl _ _ vfk _ _ _
```

The solution in your commend sorts the words by their size and then matches the words greedily.  
In this particular test case it finds the match `"kod"` and sets the corresponting element of `v` to `true`  
but then cannot match `"ak"` and `"od"` later on, even though their combination would match more characters.

I don't thin a greedy approach will work for this exercise.
The joy of solving a DP problem on your own is not something other types of problems can provide.

`Tips:-`

This is the `cutting` type dp problem where inside the recursive function, you will have to iterate through each of the index and decide the optimal position to cut.

At each cut, you will be adding a char to your current String and then you will have to call the function again.

When you cut, check whether the `currString` is in dictionary or not, if it is, it does not contribute to any extra character, but if it's not, then it's contribution will be its`length`.

Then, count the future extras by calling the function again, at then end, find the `minimum` of `currExtra+futuExtra` for all possible cut positions

How do we define " non-overlapping substrings" for this task? Are "abc" and "bcd" overlapping? are "bad" and "a" overlapping? Or should one string be inside another to be overlapping? Or should their ends have common sequences?
In `"abcd"` -> `"abc"` & `"bcd"` are overlapping, while\nIn `"abcbcd"` -> `"abc"` & `"bcd"` are not overlapping.

I spent a long time thinking that each word in dictionary can only be used once at most. I was very confused how this wasn\'t considered a hard problem. Pro tip: Thats not the case, each substring has to be a word in the dictionary, but they dont have to be different words.

I think I may have found an error in test case number 1991. When using regex on the entire dictionary, sorting the words in descending order and simply replacing all matches with an empty string, my solution gives a minimum number of extra characters of 14, while the solution states it\'s 15, which makes no sense to me, since if my solution should be wrong, my minimum remaining character should be HIGHER than the solution and not LOWER. Is there any way how I can report this testcase as I think it is wrong?
Take the test case:\n"abcde",["ae","bcd"]\nYou would remove bcd and suddenly you have ae which also matches.

Here are the words of the `dictionary` as they appear in `s`:
```
aakodubkrlauvfkzje
 ak
  kod
   od
        rl
        r
            vfk
            v
```
With `9` extra characters you can produce this:
```
_ ak od _ _ _ rl _ _ vfk _ _ _
```

The solution in your commend sorts the words by their size and then matches the words greedily.  
In this particular test case it finds the match `"kod"` and sets the corresponting element of `v` to `true`  
but then cannot match `"ak"` and `"od"` later on, even though their combination would match more characters.

I don't thin a greedy approach will work for this exercise.
The joy of solving a DP problem on your own is not something other types of problems can provide.

Le Average Leetcode  User : This description sucks

For one of the test case i got an output which is SMALLER than the expected output. 
How my algorithm does it is that ill sort the dictionary in descending order of the length of its element first, 
then for every elements in the dictionary, ill go through the string s by an increment of 1 to check whether any of the substring of s matches to that element in the dictionary. 
If it does, ill remove that substring and continue to search for the match until the new length of s is reaches. 
This process is repeated until all elements in dictionary has been searched through 
and I return the final length of s. 
I manage to get 1990 / 2028 testcases passed but was stuck with this particular testcase: 
s = "azvzulhlwxwobowijiyebeaskecvtjqwkmaqnvnaomaqnvf"
dictionary = ["na","i","edd","wobow","kecv","b","n","or","jj","zul","vk","yeb","qnfac","azv","grtjba","yswmjn","xowio","u","xi","
pcmatm","maqnv"]
my output is: 14
expected output: 15

Would appreciate anyone who can point out the flaw of my algorithm thank you
replacing the matched substring with "" creates combinations that didnt exist before
so many test cases more than 1k.
Now consider point of view of person who proposed this question, what would he suppose to do after knowing number of extra chars without knowing exact position of them?
let me guess, their depression magnitude is directly proportional to returned value of solution
Do we need to sort the dictionary of words first for better lookup time ?\n\n
`Update :` I rather put all those `dictionary` words in a `hash set` to improve the look up time.

For 50 length and 50 words, no.  I used a Trie and it was slower than a brute force "test every word against every substring" approach.  There are a number of other ways to improve on "brute force", but with such small constraints they end up being slower....
How can I solve this problem without using recursion?

Consider the case "ab", ["a","ab"].
The string contains a - length +=1
The string contains "ab" - length += 2 (=3)
Your result is therefore 2-3 = -1.
You are not checking that the words are not overlapping so you will be double counting some characters

For 50 length and 50 words, no.  I used a Trie and it was slower than a brute force "test every word against every substring" approach.  There are a number of other ways to improve on "brute force", but with such small constraints they end up being slower....
How can I solve this problem without using recursion?

Consider the case "ab", ["a","ab"].
The string contains a - length +=1
The string contains "ab" - length += 2 (=3)
Your result is therefore 2-3 = -1.
You are not checking that the words are not overlapping so you will be double counting some characters
